The commutativity of the diagrams that we have established so far shows that the first and second morphisms here equal each other, respectively. By the fact that the universal morphism into a pullback diagram is unique this implies the required identity of morphisms.

The other case is formally dual.

closure under (co-)products

Let {(A s‚Üíi sB s)‚ààKProj} s‚ààS\{(A_s \overset{i_s}{\to} B_s) \in K Proj\}_{s \in S} be a set of elements of KProjK Proj. Since colimits in the presheaf category ùíû Œî[1]\mathcal{C}^{\Delta[1]} are computed componentwise, their coproduct in this arrow category is the universal morphism out of the coproduct of objects ‚àês‚ààSA s\underset{s \in S}{\coprod} A_s induced via its universal property by the set of morphisms i si_s:

‚äîs‚ààSA s‚ü∂(i s) s‚ààS‚äîs‚ààSB s. \underset{s \in S}{\sqcup} A_s \overset{(i_s)_{s\in S}}{\longrightarrow} \underset{s \in S}{\sqcup} B_s \,.

Now let

‚äîs‚ààSA s ‚ü∂ X (i s) s‚ààS‚Üì ‚Üì ‚ààK f ‚äîs‚ààSB s ‚ü∂ Y \array{ \underset{s \in S}{\sqcup} A_s &\longrightarrow& X \\ {}^{\mathllap{(i_s)_{s\in S}}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}}_{\mathrlap{\in K}} \\ \underset{s \in S}{\sqcup} B_s &\longrightarrow& Y }

be a commuting square. This is in particular a cocone under the coproduct of objects, hence by the universal property of the coproduct, this is equivalent to a set of commuting diagrams

{A s ‚ü∂ X ‚ààKProj i s‚Üì ‚Üì ‚ààK f B s ‚ü∂ Y} s‚ààS. \left\{ \;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\; \array{ A_s &\longrightarrow& X \\ {}^{\mathllap{i_s}}_{\mathllap{\in K Proj}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}}_{\mathrlap{\in K}} \\ B_s &\longrightarrow& Y } \;\;\;\; \right\}_{s\in S} \,.

By assumption, each of these has a lift ‚Ñì s\ell_s. The collection of these lifts

{A s ‚ü∂ X ‚ààProj i s‚Üì ‚Ñì s‚Üó ‚Üì ‚ààK f B s ‚ü∂ Y} s‚ààS \left\{ \;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\; \array{ A_s &\longrightarrow& X \\ {}^{\mathllap{i_s}}_{\mathllap{\in Proj}}\downarrow &{}^{\ell_s}\nearrow& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}}_{\mathrlap{\in K}} \\ B_s &\longrightarrow& Y } \;\;\;\; \right\}_{s\in S}

is now itself a compatible cocone, and so once more by the universal property of the coproduct, this is equivalent to a lift (‚Ñì s) s‚ààS(\ell_s)_{s\in S} in the original square

‚äîs‚ààSA s ‚ü∂ X (i s) s‚ààS‚Üì (‚Ñì s) s‚ààS‚Üó ‚Üì ‚ààK f ‚äîs‚ààSB s ‚ü∂ Y. \array{ \underset{s \in S}{\sqcup} A_s &\longrightarrow& X \\ {}^{\mathllap{(i_s)_{s\in S}}}\downarrow &{}^{(\ell_s)_{s\in S}}\nearrow& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}}_{\mathrlap{\in K}} \\ \underset{s \in S}{\sqcup} B_s &\longrightarrow& Y } \,.

This shows that the coproduct of the i si_s has the left lifting property against all f‚ààKf\in K and is hence in KProjK Proj. The other case is formally dual.

An immediate consequence of prop. is this:

Corollary

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a category with all small colimits, and let K‚äÇMor(ùíû)K\subset Mor(\mathcal{C}) be a sub-class of its morphisms. Then every KK-injective morphism, def. , has the right lifting property, def. , against all KK-relative cell complexes, def. and their retracts, remark .

Remark

By a retract of a morphism X‚ü∂fYX \stackrel{f}{\longrightarrow} Y in some category ùíû\mathcal{C} we mean a retract of ff as an object in the arrow category ùíû Œî[1]\mathcal{C}^{\Delta[1]}, hence a morphism A‚ü∂gBA \stackrel{g}{\longrightarrow} B such that in ùíû Œî[1]\mathcal{C}^{\Delta[1]} there is a factorization of the identity on gg through ff

id g:g‚ü∂f‚ü∂g. id_g \;\colon\; g \longrightarrow f \longrightarrow g \,.

This means equivalently that in ùíû\mathcal{C} there is a commuting diagram of the form

id A: A ‚ü∂ X ‚ü∂ A ‚Üì g ‚Üì f ‚Üì g id B: B ‚ü∂ Y ‚ü∂ B. \array{ id_A \colon & A &\longrightarrow& X &\longrightarrow& A \\ & \downarrow^{\mathrlap{g}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{g}} \\ id_B \colon & B &\longrightarrow& Y &\longrightarrow& B } \,.
Lemma

In every category CC the class of isomorphisms is preserved under retracts in the sense of remark .

Proof

For

id A: A ‚ü∂ X ‚ü∂ A ‚Üì g ‚Üì f ‚Üì g id B: B ‚ü∂ Y ‚ü∂ B. \array{ id_A \colon & A &\longrightarrow& X &\longrightarrow& A \\ & \downarrow^{\mathrlap{g}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{g}} \\ id_B \colon & B &\longrightarrow& Y &\longrightarrow& B } \,.

a retract diagram and X‚ÜífYX \overset{f}{\to} Y an isomorphism, the inverse to A‚ÜígBA \overset{g}{\to} B is given by the composite

X ‚ü∂ A ‚Üë f ‚àí1 B ‚ü∂ Y . \array{ & & & X & \longrightarrow & A \\ & && \uparrow^{\mathrlap{f^{-1}}} && \\ & B & \longrightarrow& Y&& } \,.

More generally:

Proposition

Given a model category in the sense of def. , then its class of weak equivalences is closed under forming retracts (in the arrow category, see remark ).

(Joyal, prop. E.1.3)

Proof

Let

id: A ‚ü∂ X ‚ü∂ A f‚Üì ‚Üì w ‚Üì f id: B ‚ü∂ Y ‚ü∂ B \array{ id \colon & A &\longrightarrow& X &\longrightarrow& A \\ & {}^{\mathllap{f}} \downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{w}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}} \\ id \colon & B &\longrightarrow& Y &\longrightarrow& B }

be a commuting diagram in the given model category, with w‚ààWw \in W a weak equivalence. We need to show that then also f‚ààWf \in W.

First consider the case that f‚ààFibf \in Fib.

In this case, factor ww as a cofibration followed by an acyclic fibration. Since w‚ààWw \in W and by two-out-of-three (def. ) this is even a factorization through an acyclic cofibration followed by an acyclic fibration. Hence we obtain a commuting diagram of the following form:

id: A ‚ü∂ X ‚ü∂AAAA A id‚Üì ‚Üì ‚ààW‚à©Cof ‚Üì id id: A‚Ä≤ ‚ü∂s X‚Ä≤ ‚ü∂AAtAA A‚Ä≤ ‚ààFib f‚Üì ‚Üì ‚ààW‚à©Fib ‚Üì ‚ààFib f id: B ‚ü∂ Y ‚ü∂AAAA B, \array{ id \colon & A &\longrightarrow& X &\overset{\phantom{AAAA}}{\longrightarrow}& A \\ & {}^{\mathllap{id}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in W \cap Cof}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{id}} \\ id \colon & A' &\overset{s}{\longrightarrow}& X' &\overset{\phantom{AA}t\phantom{AA}}{\longrightarrow}& A' \\ & {}^{\mathllap{f}}_{\mathllap{\in Fib}} \downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in W \cap Fib}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}}_{\mathrlap{\in Fib}} \\ id \colon & B &\longrightarrow& Y &\underset{\phantom{AAAA}}{\longrightarrow}& B } \,,

where ss is uniquely defined and where tt is any lift of the top middle vertical acyclic cofibration against ff. This now exhibits ff as a retract of an acyclic fibration. These are closed under retract by prop. .

Now consider the general case. Factor ff as an acyclic cofibration followed by a fibration and form the pushout in the top left square of the following diagram

id: A ‚ü∂ X ‚ü∂AAAA A ‚ààW‚à©Cof‚Üì (po) ‚Üì ‚ààW‚à©Cof ‚Üì ‚ààW‚à©Cof id: A‚Ä≤ ‚ü∂ X‚Ä≤ ‚ü∂AAAA A‚Ä≤ ‚ààFib‚Üì ‚Üì ‚ààW ‚Üì ‚ààFib id: B ‚ü∂ Y ‚ü∂AAAA B, \array{ id \colon & A &\longrightarrow& X &\overset{\phantom{AAAA}}{\longrightarrow}& A \\ & {}^{\mathllap{\in W \cap Cof}}\downarrow &(po)& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in W \cap Cof}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in W \cap Cof}} \\ id \colon & A' &\overset{}{\longrightarrow}& X' &\overset{\phantom{AA}\phantom{AA}}{\longrightarrow}& A' \\ & {}^{\mathllap{\in Fib}} \downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in W }} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in Fib}} \\ id \colon & B &\longrightarrow& Y &\underset{\phantom{AAAA}}{\longrightarrow}& B } \,,

where the other three squares are induced by the universal property of the pushout, as is the identification of the middle horizontal composite as the identity on A‚Ä≤A'. Since acyclic cofibrations are closed under forming pushouts by prop. , the top middle vertical morphism is now an acyclic fibration, and hence by assumption and by two-out-of-three so is the middle bottom vertical morphism.

Thus the previous case now gives that the bottom left vertical morphism is a weak equivalence, and hence the total left vertical composite is.

Lemma

(retract argument)

Consider a composite morphism

f:X‚ü∂iA‚ü∂pY. f \;\colon\; X \stackrel{i}{\longrightarrow} A \stackrel{p}{\longrightarrow} Y \,.

  1. If ff has the left lifting property against pp, then ff is a retract of ii.

  2. If ff has the right lifting property against ii, then ff is a retract of pp.

Proof

We discuss the first statement, the second is formally dual.

Write the factorization of ff as a commuting square of the form

X ‚ü∂i A f‚Üì ‚Üì p Y = Y. \array{ X &\stackrel{i}{\longrightarrow}& A \\ {}^{\mathllap{f}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p}} \\ Y &= & Y } \,.

By the assumed lifting property of ff against pp there exists a diagonal filler gg making a commuting diagram of the form

X ‚ü∂i A f‚Üì g‚Üó ‚Üì p Y = Y. \array{ X &\stackrel{i}{\longrightarrow}& A \\ {}^{\mathllap{f}}\downarrow &{}^{\mathllap{g}}\nearrow& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p}} \\ Y &= & Y } \,.

By rearranging this diagram a little, it is equivalent to

X = X f‚Üì i‚Üì id Y: Y ‚ü∂g A ‚ü∂p Y. \array{ & X &=& X \\ & {}^{\mathllap{f}}\downarrow && {}^{\mathllap{i}}\downarrow \\ id_Y \colon & Y &\underset{g}{\longrightarrow}& A &\underset{p}{\longrightarrow}& Y } \,.

Completing this to the right, this yields a diagram exhibiting the required retract according to remark :

id X: X = X = X f‚Üì i‚Üì f‚Üì id Y: Y ‚ü∂g A ‚ü∂p Y. \array{ id_X \colon & X &=& X &=& X \\ & {}^{\mathllap{f}}\downarrow && {}^{\mathllap{i}}\downarrow && {}^{\mathllap{f}}\downarrow \\ id_Y \colon & Y &\underset{g}{\longrightarrow}& A &\underset{p}{\longrightarrow}& Y } \,.

Small object argument

Given a set C‚äÇMor(ùíû)C \subset Mor(\mathcal{C}) of morphisms in some category ùíû\mathcal{C}, a natural question is how to factor any given morphism f:X‚ü∂Yf\colon X \longrightarrow Y through a relative CC-cell complex, def. , followed by a CC-injective morphism, def.

f:X‚ü∂‚ààCcellX^‚ü∂‚ààCinjY. f \;\colon\; X \stackrel{\in C cell}{\longrightarrow} \hat X \stackrel{\in C inj}{\longrightarrow} Y \,.

A first approximation to such a factorization turns out to be given simply by forming X^=X 1\hat X = X_1 by attaching all possible CC-cells to XX. Namely let

(C/f)‚âî{dom(c) ‚ü∂ X c‚ààC‚Üì ‚Üì f cod(c) ‚ü∂ Y} (C/f) \coloneqq \left\{ \array{ dom(c) &\stackrel{}{\longrightarrow}& X \\ {}^{\mathllap{c\in C}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}} \\ cod(c) &\longrightarrow& Y } \right\}

be the set of all ways to find a CC-cell attachment in ff, and consider the pushout X^\hat X of the coproduct of morphisms in CC over all these:

‚àêc‚àà(C/f)dom(c) ‚ü∂ X ‚àêc‚àà(C/f)c‚Üì (po) ‚Üì ‚àêc‚àà(C/f)cod(c) ‚ü∂ X 1. \array{ \underset{c\in(C/f)}{\coprod} dom(c) &\longrightarrow& X \\ {}^{\mathllap{\underset{c\in(C/f)}{\coprod} c}}\downarrow &(po)& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{}} \\ \underset{c\in(C/f)}{\coprod} cod(c) &\longrightarrow& X_1 } \,.

This gets already close to producing the intended factorization:

First of all the resulting map X‚ÜíX 1X \to X_1 is a CC-relative cell complex, by construction.

Second, by the fact that the coproduct is over all commuting squres to ff, the morphism ff itself makes a commuting diagram

‚àêc‚àà(C/f)dom(c) ‚ü∂ X ‚àêc‚àà(C/f)c‚Üì ‚Üì f ‚àêc‚àà(C/f)cod(c) ‚ü∂ Y \array{ \underset{c\in(C/f)}{\coprod} dom(c) &\longrightarrow& X \\ {}^{\mathllap{\underset{c\in(C/f)}{\coprod} c}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}} \\ \underset{c\in(C/f)}{\coprod} cod(c) &\longrightarrow& Y }

and hence the universal property of the colimit means that ff is indeed factored through that CC-cell complex X 1X_1; we may suggestively arrange that factorizing diagram like so:

‚àêc‚àà(C/f)dom(c) ‚ü∂ X id‚Üì ‚Üì ‚àêc‚àà(C/f)dom(c) X 1 ‚àêc‚àà(C/f)c‚Üì ‚Üó ‚Üì ‚àêc‚àà(C/f)cod(c) ‚ü∂ Y. \array{ \underset{c\in(C/f)}{\coprod} dom(c) &\longrightarrow& X \\ {}^{\mathllap{id}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{}} \\ \underset{c\in(C/f)}{\coprod} dom(c) && X_1 \\ {}^{\mathllap{\underset{c\in(C/f)}{\coprod} c}}\downarrow &\nearrow& \downarrow \\ \underset{c\in(C/f)}{\coprod} cod(c) &\longrightarrow& Y } \,.

This shows that, finally, the colimiting co-cone map ‚Äì the one that now appears diagonally ‚Äì almost exhibits the desired right lifting of X 1‚ÜíYX_1 \to Y against the c‚ààCc\in C. The failure of that to hold on the nose is only the fact that a horizontal map in the middle of the above diagram is missing: the diagonal map obtained above lifts not all commuting diagrams of c‚ààCc\in C into ff, but only those where the top morphism dom(c)‚ÜíX 1dom(c) \to X_1 factors through X‚ÜíX 1X \to X_1.

The idea of the small object argument now is to fix this only remaining problem by iterating the construction: next factor X 1‚ÜíYX_1 \to Y in the same way into

X 1‚ü∂X 2‚ü∂Y X_1 \longrightarrow X_2 \longrightarrow Y

and so forth. Since relative CC-cell complexes are closed under composition, at stage nn the resulting X‚ü∂X nX \longrightarrow X_n is still a CC-cell complex, getting bigger and bigger. But accordingly, the failure of the accompanying X n‚ü∂YX_n \longrightarrow Y to be a CC-injective morphism becomes smaller and smaller, for it now lifts against all diagrams where dom(c)‚ü∂X ndom(c) \longrightarrow X_n factors through X n‚àí1‚ü∂X nX_{n-1}\longrightarrow X_n, which intuitively is less and less of a condition as the X n‚àí1X_{n-1} grow larger and larger.

The concept of small object is just what makes this intuition precise and finishes the small object argument. For the present purpose we just need the following simple version:

Definition

For ùíû\mathcal{C} a category and C‚äÇMor(ùíû)C \subset Mor(\mathcal{C}) a sub-set of its morphisms, say that these have small domains if there is an ordinal Œ±\alpha (def. ) such that for every c‚ààCc\in C and for every CC-relative cell complex given by a transfinite composition (def. )

f:X‚ÜíX 1‚ÜíX 2‚Üí‚ãØ‚ÜíX Œ≤‚Üí‚ãØ‚ü∂X^ f \;\colon\; X \to X_1 \to X_2 \to \cdots \to X_\beta \to \cdots \longrightarrow \hat X

every morphism dom(c)‚ü∂X^dom(c)\longrightarrow \hat X factors through a stage X Œ≤‚ÜíX^X_\beta \to \hat X of order Œ≤<Œ±\beta \lt \alpha:

X Œ≤ ‚Üó ‚Üì dom(c) ‚ü∂ X^. \array{ && X_\beta \\ & \nearrow & \downarrow \\ dom(c) &\longrightarrow& \hat X } \,.

The above discussion proves the following:

Proposition

(small object argument)

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a locally small category with all small colimits. If a set C‚äÇMor(ùíû)C\subset Mor(\mathcal{C}) of morphisms has all small domains in the sense of def. , then every morphism f:X‚ü∂Yf\colon X\longrightarrow Y in ùíû\mathcal{C} factors through a CC-relative cell complex, def. , followed by a CC-injective morphism, def.

f:X‚ü∂‚ààCcellX^‚ü∂‚ààCinjY. f \;\colon\; X \stackrel{\in C cell}{\longrightarrow} \hat X \stackrel{\in C inj}{\longrightarrow} Y \,.

(Quillen 67, II.3 lemma)

Homotopy

We discuss how the concept of homotopy is abstractly realized in model categories, def. .

Definition

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a model category, def. , and X‚ààùíûX \in \mathcal{C} an object.

  • A path space object Path(X)Path(X) for XX is a factorization of the diagonal Œî X:X‚ÜíX√óX\Delta_X \;\colon\; X \to X \times X as
Œî X:X‚ü∂‚ààWiPath(X)‚ü∂‚ààFib(p 0,p 1)X√óX. \Delta_X \;\colon\; X \underoverset{\in W}{i}{\longrightarrow} Path(X) \underoverset{\in Fib}{(p_0,p_1)}{\longrightarrow} X \times X \,.

where X‚ÜíPath(X)X\to Path(X) is a weak equivalence and Path(X)‚ÜíX√óXPath(X) \to X \times X is a fibration.

  • A cylinder object Cyl(X)Cyl(X) for XX is a factorization of the codiagonal (or ‚Äúfold map‚Äù) ‚àá X:X‚äîX‚ÜíX\nabla_X \;\colon\; X \sqcup X \to X as
‚àá X:X‚äîX‚ü∂‚ààCof(i 0,i 1)Cyl(X)‚ü∂‚ààWpX. \nabla_X \;\colon\; X \sqcup X \underoverset{\in Cof}{(i_0,i_1)}{\longrightarrow} Cyl(X) \underoverset{\in W}{p}{\longrightarrow} X \,.

where Cyl(X)‚ÜíXCyl(X) \to X is a weak equivalence. and X‚äîX‚ÜíCyl(X)X \sqcup X \to Cyl(X) is a cofibration.

Remark

For every object X‚ààùíûX \in \mathcal{C} in a model category, a cylinder object and a path space object according to def. exist: the factorization axioms guarantee that there exists

  1. a factorization of the codiagonal as

    ‚àá X:X‚äîX‚ü∂‚ààCofCyl(X)‚ü∂‚ààW‚à©FibX \nabla_X \;\colon\; X \sqcup X \overset{\in Cof}{\longrightarrow} Cyl(X) \overset{\in W \cap Fib}{\longrightarrow} X

  2. a factorization of the diagonal as

    Œî X:X‚ü∂‚ààW‚à©CofPath(X)‚ü∂‚ààFibX√óX. \Delta_X \;\colon\; X \overset{\in W \cap Cof}{\longrightarrow} Path(X) \overset{\in Fib}{\longrightarrow} X \times X \,.

The cylinder and path space objects obtained this way are actually better than required by def. : in addition to Cyl(X)‚ÜíXCyl(X)\to X being just a weak equivalence, for these this is actually an acyclic fibration, and dually in addition to X‚ÜíPath(X)X\to Path(X) being a weak equivalence, for these it is actually an acyclic cofibration.

Some authors call cylinder/path-space objects with this extra property ‚Äúvery good‚Äù cylinder/path-space objects, respectively.

One may also consider dropping a condition in def. : what mainly matters is the weak equivalence, hence some authors take cylinder/path-space objects to be defined as in def. but without the condition that X‚äîX‚ÜíCyl(X)X \sqcup X\to Cyl(X) is a cofibration and without the condition that Path(X)‚ÜíX√óXPath(X) \to X\times X is a fibration. Such authors would then refer to the concept in def. as ‚Äúgood‚Äù cylinder/path-space objects.

The terminology in def. follows the original (Quillen 67, I.1 def. 4). With the induced concept of left/right homotopy below in def. , this admits a quick derivation of the key facts in the following, as we spell out below.

Lemma

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a model category. If X‚ààùíûX \in \mathcal{C} is cofibrant, then for every cylinder object Cyl(X)Cyl(X) of XX, def. , not only is (i 0,i 1):X‚äîX‚ÜíX(i_0,i_1) \colon X \sqcup X \to X a cofibration, but each

i 0,i 1:X‚ü∂Cyl(X) i_0, i_1 \colon X \longrightarrow Cyl(X)

is an acyclic cofibration separately.

Dually, if X‚ààùíûX \in \mathcal{C} is fibrant, then for every path space object Path(X)Path(X) of XX, def. , not only is (p 0,p 1):Path(X)‚ÜíX√óX(p_0,p_1) \colon Path(X)\to X \times X a fibration, but each

p 0,p 1:Path(X)‚ü∂X p_0, p_1 \colon Path(X) \longrightarrow X

is an acyclic fibration separately.

Proof

We discuss the case of the path space object. The other case is formally dual.

First, that the component maps are weak equivalences follows generally: by definition they have a right inverse Path(X)‚ÜíXPath(X) \to X and so this follows by two-out-of-three (def. ).

But if XX is fibrant, then also the two projection maps out of the product X√óX‚ÜíXX \times X \to X are fibrations, because they are both pullbacks of the fibration X‚Üí*X \to \ast

X√óX ‚ü∂ X ‚Üì (pb) ‚Üì X ‚ü∂ *. \array{ X\times X &\longrightarrow& X \\ \downarrow &(pb)& \downarrow \\ X &\longrightarrow& \ast } \,.

hence p i:Path(X)‚ÜíX√óX‚ÜíXp_i \colon Path(X)\to X \times X \to X is the composite of two fibrations, and hence itself a fibration, by prop. .

Path space objects are very non-unique as objects up to isomorphism:

Example

If X‚ààùíûX \in \mathcal{C} is a fibrant object in a model category, def. , and for Path 1(X)Path_1(X) and Path 2(X)Path_2(X) two path space objects for XX, def. , then the fiber product Path 1(X)√ó XPath 2(X)Path_1(X) \times_X Path_2(X) is another path space object for XX: the pullback square

X ‚ü∂Œî X X√óX ‚Üì ‚Üì Path 1(X)√óXPath 2(X) ‚ü∂ Path 1(X)√óPath 2(X) ‚ààFib‚Üì (pb) ‚Üì ‚ààFib X√óX√óX ‚ü∂(id,Œî X,id) X√óX√óX√óX ‚Üì ‚ààFib (pr 1,pr 3) ‚Üì (p 1,p 4) X√óX = X√óX \array{ X &\overset{\Delta_X}{\longrightarrow}& X \times X \\ \downarrow && \downarrow \\ Path_1(X) \underset{X}{\times} Path_2(X) &\longrightarrow& Path_1(X)\times Path_2(X) \\ {}^{\mathllap{\in Fib}}\downarrow &(pb)& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in Fib}} \\ X \times X \times X &\overset{(id,\Delta_X,id)}{\longrightarrow}& X \times X\times X \times X \\ \downarrow^{\mathrlap{(pr_1,pr_3)}}_{\mathrlap{\in Fib}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{(p_1, p_4)}} \\ X\times X &=& X \times X }

gives that the induced projection is again a fibration. Moreover, using lemma and two-out-of-three (def. ) gives that X‚ÜíPath 1(X)√ó XPath 2(X)X \to Path_1(X) \times_X Path_2(X) is a weak equivalence.

For the case of the canonical topological path space objects of def , with Path 1(X)=Path 2(X)=X I=X [0,1]Path_1(X) = Path_2(X) = X^I = X^{[0,1]} then this new path space object is X I‚à®I=X [0,2]X^{I \vee I} = X^{[0,2]}, the mapping space out of the standard interval of length 2 instead of length 1.

Definition

Let f,g:X‚ü∂Yf,g \colon X \longrightarrow Y be two parallel morphisms in a model category.

  • A left homotopy Œ∑:f‚áí Lg\eta \colon f \Rightarrow_L g is a morphism Œ∑:Cyl(X)‚ü∂Y\eta \colon Cyl(X) \longrightarrow Y from a cylinder object of XX, def. , such that it makes this diagram commute:
X ‚ü∂ Cyl(X) ‚üµ X f‚Üò ‚Üì Œ∑ ‚Üô g Y. \array{ X &\longrightarrow& Cyl(X) &\longleftarrow& X \\ & {}_{\mathllap{f}}\searrow &\downarrow^{\mathrlap{\eta}}& \swarrow_{\mathrlap{g}} \\ && Y } \,.
  • A right homotopy Œ∑:f‚áí Rg\eta \colon f \Rightarrow_R g is a morphism Œ∑:X‚ÜíPath(Y)\eta \colon X \to Path(Y) to some path space object of YY, def. , such that this diagram commutes:
X f‚Üô ‚Üì Œ∑ ‚Üò g Y ‚üµ Path(Y) ‚ü∂ Y. \array{ && X \\ & {}^{\mathllap{f}}\swarrow & \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\eta}} & \searrow^{\mathrlap{g}} \\ Y &\longleftarrow& Path(Y) &\longrightarrow& Y } \,.
Lemma

Let f,g:X‚ÜíYf,g \colon X \to Y be two parallel morphisms in a model category.

  1. Let XX be cofibrant. If there is a left homotopy f‚áí Lgf \Rightarrow_L g then there is also a right homotopy f‚áí Rgf \Rightarrow_R g (def. ) with respect to any chosen path space object.

  2. Let YY be fibrant. If there is a right homotopy f‚áí Rgf \Rightarrow_R g then there is also a left homotopy f‚áí Lgf \Rightarrow_L g with respect to any chosen cylinder object.

In particular if XX is cofibrant and YY is fibrant, then by going back and forth it follows that every left homotopy is exhibited by every cylinder object, and every right homotopy is exhibited by every path space object.

Proof

We discuss the first case, the second is formally dual. Let Œ∑:Cyl(X)‚ü∂Y\eta \colon Cyl(X) \longrightarrow Y be the given left homotopy. Lemma implies that we have a lift hh in the following commuting diagram

X ‚ü∂i‚àòf Path(Y) ‚ààW‚à©Cof i 0‚Üì h‚Üó ‚Üì ‚ààFib p 0,p 1 Cyl(X) ‚ü∂(f‚àòp,Œ∑) Y√óY, \array{ X &\overset{i \circ f}{\longrightarrow}& Path(Y) \\ {}^{\mathllap{i_0}}_{\mathllap{\in W \cap Cof}}\downarrow &{}^{\mathllap{h}}\nearrow& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p_0,p_1}}_{\mathrlap{\in Fib}} \\ Cyl(X) &\underset{(f \circ p,\eta)}{\longrightarrow}& Y \times Y } \,,

where on the right we have the chosen path space object. Now the composite Œ∑Àú‚âîh‚àòi 1\tilde \eta \coloneqq h \circ i_1 is a right homotopy as required:

Path(Y) h‚Üó ‚Üì ‚ààFib p 0,p 1 X ‚ü∂i 1 Cyl(X) ‚ü∂(f‚àòp,Œ∑) Y√óY. \array{ && && Path(Y) \\ && &{}^{\mathllap{h}}\nearrow& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p_0,p_1}}_{\mathrlap{\in Fib}} \\ X &\overset{i_1}{\longrightarrow}& Cyl(X) &\underset{(f \circ p,\eta)}{\longrightarrow}& Y \times Y } \,.
Proposition

For XX a cofibrant object in a model category and YY a fibrant object, the relations of left homotopy f‚áí Lgf \Rightarrow_L g and of right homotopy f‚áí Rgf \Rightarrow_R g (def. ) on the hom set Hom(X,Y)Hom(X,Y) coincide and are both equivalence relations.

Proof

That both relations coincide under the (co-)fibrancy assumption follows directly from lemma .

The symmetry and reflexivity of the relation is obvious.

That right homotopy (hence also left homotopy) with domain XX is a transitive relation follows from using example to compose path space objects.

The homotopy category

We discuss the construction that takes a model category, def. , and then universally forces all its weak equivalences into actual isomorphisms.

Definition

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a model category, def. . Write Ho(ùíû)Ho(\mathcal{C}) for the category whose

  • objects are those objects of ùíû\mathcal{C} which are both fibrant and cofibrant;

  • morphisms are the homotopy classes of morphisms of ùíû\mathcal{C}, hence the equivalence classes of morphism under the equivalence relation of prop. ;

and whose composition operation is given on representatives by composition in ùíû\mathcal{C}.

This is, up to equivalence of categories, the homotopy category of the model category ùíû\mathcal{C}.

Proposition

Def. is well defined, in that composition of morphisms between fibrant-cofibrant objects in ùíû\mathcal{C} indeed passes to homotopy classes.

Proof

Fix any morphism X‚ÜífYX \overset{f}{\to} Y between fibrant-cofibrant objects. Then for precomposition

(‚àí)‚àò[f]:Hom Ho(ùíû)(Y,Z)‚ÜíHom Ho(ùíû)(X,Z) (-) \circ [f] \;\colon\; Hom_{Ho(\mathcal{C})}(Y,Z) \to Hom_{Ho(\mathcal{C})}(X,Z)

to be well defined, we need that with (g‚àºh):Y‚ÜíZ(g\sim h)\;\colon\; Y \to Z also (fg‚àºfh):X‚ÜíZ(f g \sim f h)\;\colon\; X \to Z. But by prop we may take the homotopy ‚àº\sim to be exhibited by a right homotopy Œ∑:Y‚ÜíPath(Z)\eta \colon Y \to Path(Z), for which case the statement is evident from this diagram:

Z g‚Üó ‚Üë p 1 X ‚ü∂f Y ‚ü∂Œ∑ Path(Z) h‚Üò ‚Üì p 0 Z. \array{ && && Z \\ && & {}^{\mathllap{g}}\nearrow & \uparrow^{\mathrlap{p_1}} \\ X &\overset{f}{\longrightarrow} & Y &\overset{\eta}{\longrightarrow}& Path(Z) \\ && & {}_{\mathllap{h}}\searrow & \downarrow_{\mathrlap{p_0}} \\ && && Z } \,.

For postcomposition we may choose to exhibit homotopy by left homotopy and argue dually.

We now spell out that def. indeed satisfies the universal property that defines the localization of a category with weak equivalences at its weak equivalences.

Lemma

(Whitehead theorem in model categories)

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a model category. A weak equivalence between two objects which are both fibrant and cofibrant is a homotopy equivalence.

Proof

By the factorization axioms in the model category ùíû\mathcal{C} and by two-out-of-three (def. ), every weak equivalence f:X‚ü∂Yf\colon X \longrightarrow Y factors through an object ZZ as an acyclic cofibration followed by an acyclic fibration. In particular it follows that with XX and YY both fibrant and cofibrant, so is ZZ, and hence it is sufficient to prove that acyclic (co-)fibrations between such objects are homotopy equivalences.

So let f:X‚ü∂Yf \colon X \longrightarrow Y be an acyclic fibration between fibrant-cofibrant objects, the case of acyclic cofibrations is formally dual. Then in fact it has a genuine right inverse given by a lift f ‚àí1f^{-1} in the diagram

‚àÖ ‚Üí X ‚ààcof‚Üì f ‚àí1‚Üó ‚Üì ‚ààFib‚à©W f Y = Y. \array{ \emptyset &\rightarrow& X \\ {}^{\mathllap{\in cof}}\downarrow &{}^{{f^{-1}}}\nearrow& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}}_{\mathrlap{\in Fib \cap W}} \\ Y &=& Y } \,.

To see that f ‚àí1f^{-1} is also a left inverse up to left homotopy, let Cyl(X)Cyl(X) be any cylinder object on XX (def. ), hence a factorization of the codiagonal on XX as a cofibration followed by a an acyclic fibration

X‚äîX‚ü∂Œπ XCyl(X)‚ü∂pX X \sqcup X \stackrel{\iota_X}{\longrightarrow} Cyl(X) \stackrel{p}{\longrightarrow} X

and consider the commuting square

X‚äîX ‚ü∂(f ‚àí1‚àòf,id) X Œπ X ‚ààCof‚Üì ‚Üì ‚ààW‚à©Fib f Cyl(X) ‚ü∂f‚àòp Y, \array{ X \sqcup X &\stackrel{(f^{-1}\circ f, id)}{\longrightarrow}& X \\ {}^{\mathllap{\iota_X}}{}_{\mathllap{\in Cof}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}}_{\mathrlap{\in W \cap Fib}} \\ Cyl(X) &\underset{f\circ p}{\longrightarrow}& Y } \,,

which commutes due to f ‚àí1f^{-1} being a genuine right inverse of ff. By construction, this commuting square now admits a lift Œ∑\eta, and that constitutes a left homotopy Œ∑:f ‚àí1‚àòf‚áí Lid\eta \colon f^{-1}\circ f \Rightarrow_L id.

Definition

Given a model category ùíû\mathcal{C}, consider a choice for each object X‚ààùíûX \in \mathcal{C} of

  1. a factorization ‚àÖ‚ü∂‚ààCofi XQX‚ü∂‚ààW‚à©Fibp XX\emptyset \underoverset{\in Cof}{i_X}{\longrightarrow} Q X \underoverset{\in W \cap Fib}{p_X}{\longrightarrow} X of the initial morphism, such that when XX is already cofibrant then p X=id Xp_X = id_X;

  2. a factorization X‚ü∂‚ààW‚à©Cofj XPX‚ü∂‚ààFibq X*X \underoverset{\in W \cap Cof}{j_X}{\longrightarrow} P X \underoverset{\in Fib}{q_X}{\longrightarrow} \ast of the terminal morphism, such that when XX is already fibrant then j X=id Xj_X = id_X.

Write then

Œ≥ P,Q:ùíû‚ü∂Ho(ùíû) \gamma_{P,Q} \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow Ho(\mathcal{C})

for the functor to the homotopy category, def. , which sends an object XX to the object PQXP Q X and sends a morphism f:X‚ü∂Yf \colon X \longrightarrow Y to the homotopy class of the result of first lifting in

‚àÖ ‚ü∂ QY i X‚Üì Qf‚Üó ‚Üì p Y QX ‚ü∂f‚àòp X Y \array{ \emptyset &\longrightarrow& Q Y \\ {}^{\mathllap{i_X}}\downarrow &{}^{Q f}\nearrow& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p_Y}} \\ Q X &\underset{f\circ p_X}{\longrightarrow}& Y }

and then lifting (here: extending) in

QX ‚ü∂j QY‚àòQf PQY j QX‚Üì PQf‚Üó ‚Üì q QY PQX ‚ü∂ *. \array{ Q X &\overset{j_{Q Y} \circ Q f}{\longrightarrow}& P Q Y \\ {}^{\mathllap{j_{Q X}}}\downarrow &{}^{P Q f}\nearrow& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{q_{Q Y}}} \\ P Q X &\longrightarrow& \ast } \,.
Lemma

The construction in def. is indeed well defined.

Proof

First of all, the object PQXP Q X is indeed both fibrant and cofibrant (as well as related by a zig-zag of weak equivalences to XX):

‚àÖ ‚ààCof‚Üì ‚Üò ‚ààCof QX ‚ü∂‚ààW‚à©Cof PQX ‚ü∂‚ààFib * ‚ààW‚Üì X. \array{ \emptyset \\ {}^{\mathllap{\in Cof}}\downarrow & \searrow^{\mathrlap{\in Cof}} \\ Q X &\underset{\in W \cap Cof}{\longrightarrow}& P Q X &\underset{\in Fib}{\longrightarrow}& \ast \\ {}^{\mathllap{\in W}}\downarrow \\ X } \,.

Now to see that the image on morphisms is well defined. First observe that any two choices (Qf) i(Q f)_{i} of the first lift in the definition are left homotopic to each other, exhibited by lifting in

QX‚äîQX ‚ü∂((Qf) 1,(Qf) 2) QY ‚ààCof‚Üì ‚Üì ‚ààW‚à©Fib p Y Cyl(QX) ‚ü∂f‚àòp X‚àòœÉ QX Y. \array{ Q X \sqcup Q X &\stackrel{((Q f)_1, (Q f)_2 )}{\longrightarrow}& Q Y \\ {}^{\mathllap{\in Cof}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p_{Y}}}_{\mathrlap{\in W \cap Fib}} \\ Cyl(Q X) &\underset{f \circ p_{X} \circ \sigma_{Q X}}{\longrightarrow}& Y } \,.

Hence also the composites j QY‚àò(Q f) ij_{Q Y}\circ (Q_f)_i are left homotopic to each other, and since their domain is cofibrant, then by lemma they are also right homotopic by a right homotopy Œ∫\kappa. This implies finally, by lifting in

QX ‚ü∂Œ∫ Path(PQY) ‚ààW‚à©Cof‚Üì ‚Üì ‚ààFib PQX ‚ü∂(P(Qf) 1,P(Qf) 2) PQY√óPQY \array{ Q X &\overset{\kappa}{\longrightarrow}& Path(P Q Y) \\ {}^{\mathllap{\in W \cap Cof}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in Fib}} \\ P Q X &\underset{(P (Q f)_1, P (Q f)_2)}{\longrightarrow}& P Q Y \times P Q Y }

that also P(Qf) 1P (Q f)_1 and P(Qf) 2P (Q f)_2 are right homotopic, hence that indeed PQfP Q f represents a well-defined homotopy class.

Finally to see that the assignment is indeed functorial, observe that the commutativity of the lifting diagrams for QfQ f and PQfP Q f imply that also the following diagram commutes

X ‚üµp X QX ‚ü∂j QX PQX f‚Üì ‚Üì Qf ‚Üì PQf Y ‚üµp y QY ‚ü∂j QY PQY. \array{ X &\overset{p_X}{\longleftarrow}& Q X &\overset{j_{Q X}}{\longrightarrow}& P Q X \\ {}^{\mathllap{f}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{Q f}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{P Q f}} \\ Y &\underset{p_y}{\longleftarrow}& Q Y &\underset{j_{Q Y}}{\longrightarrow}& P Q Y } \,.

Now from the pasting composite

X ‚üµp X QX ‚ü∂j QX PQX f‚Üì ‚Üì Qf ‚Üì PQf Y ‚üµp Y QY ‚ü∂j QY PQY g‚Üì ‚Üì Qg ‚Üì PQg Z ‚üµp Z QZ ‚ü∂j QZ PQZ \array{ X &\overset{p_X}{\longleftarrow}& Q X &\overset{j_{Q X}}{\longrightarrow}& P Q X \\ {}^{\mathllap{f}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{Q f}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{P Q f}} \\ Y &\underset{p_Y}{\longleftarrow}& Q Y &\underset{j_{Q Y}}{\longrightarrow}& P Q Y \\ {}^{\mathllap{g}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{Q g}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{P Q g}} \\ Z &\underset{p_Z}{\longleftarrow}& Q Z &\underset{j_{Q Z}}{\longrightarrow}& P Q Z }

one sees that (PQg)‚àò(PQf)(P Q g)\circ (P Q f) is a lift of g‚àòfg \circ f and hence the same argument as above gives that it is homotopic to the chosen PQ(g‚àòf)P Q(g \circ f).

For the following, recall the concept of natural isomorphism between functors: for F,G:ùíû‚ü∂ùíüF, G \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow \mathcal{D} two functors, then a natural transformation Œ∑:F‚áíG\eta \colon F \Rightarrow G is for each object c‚ààObj(ùíû)c \in Obj(\mathcal{C}) a morphism Œ∑ c:F(c)‚ü∂G(c)\eta_c \colon F(c) \longrightarrow G(c) in ùíü\mathcal{D}, such that for each morphism f:c 1‚Üíc 2f \colon c_1 \to c_2 in ùíû\mathcal{C} the following is a commuting square:

F(c 1) ‚ü∂Œ∑ c 1 G(c 1) F(f)‚Üì ‚Üì G(f) F(c 2) ‚ü∂Œ∑ c 2 G(c 2). \array{ F(c_1) &\overset{\eta_{c_1}}{\longrightarrow}& G(c_1) \\ {}^{\mathllap{F(f)}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{G(f)}} \\ F(c_2) &\underset{\eta_{c_2}}{\longrightarrow}& G(c_2) } \,.

Such Œ∑\eta is called a natural isomorphism if its Œ∑ c\eta_c are isomorphisms for all objects cc.

Definition

For ùíû\mathcal{C} a category with weak equivalences, its localization at the weak equivalences is, if it exists,

  1. a category denoted ùíû[W ‚àí1]\mathcal{C}[W^{-1}]

  2. a functor

    Œ≥:ùíû‚ü∂ùíû[W ‚àí1] \gamma \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow \mathcal{C}[W^{-1}]

such that

  1. Œ≥\gamma sends weak equivalences to isomorphisms;

  2. Œ≥\gamma is universal with this property, in that:

    for F:ùíû‚ü∂DF \colon \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow D any functor out of ùíû\mathcal{C} into any category DD, such that FF takes weak equivalences to isomorphisms, it factors through Œ≥\gamma up to a natural isomorphism œÅ\rho

    ùíû ‚ü∂F D Œ≥‚Üò ‚áì œÅ ‚Üó FÀú Ho(ùíû) \array{ \mathcal{C} && \overset{F}{\longrightarrow} && D \\ & {}_{\mathllap{\gamma}}\searrow &\Downarrow^{\rho}& \nearrow_{\mathrlap{\tilde F}} \\ && Ho(\mathcal{C}) }

    and this factorization is unique up to unique isomorphism, in that for (FÀú 1,œÅ 1)(\tilde F_1, \rho_1) and (FÀú 2,œÅ 2)(\tilde F_2, \rho_2) two such factorizations, then there is a unique natural isomorphism Œ∫:FÀú 1‚áíFÀú 2\kappa \colon \tilde F_1 \Rightarrow \tilde F_2 making the evident diagram of natural isomorphisms commute.

Theorem

For ùíû\mathcal{C} a model category, the functor Œ≥ P,Q\gamma_{P,Q} in def. (for any choice of PP and QQ) exhibits Ho(ùíû)Ho(\mathcal{C}) as indeed being the localization of the underlying category with weak equivalences at its weak equivalences, in the sense of def. :

ùíû = ùíû Œ≥ P,Q‚Üì ‚Üì Œ≥ Ho(ùíû) ‚âÉ ùíû[W ‚àí1]. \array{ \mathcal{C} &=& \mathcal{C} \\ {}^{\mathllap{\gamma_{P,Q}}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\gamma}} \\ Ho(\mathcal{C}) &\simeq& \mathcal{C}[W^{-1}] } \,.

(Quillen 67, I.1 theorem 1)

Proof

First, to see that that Œ≥ P,Q\gamma_{P,Q} indeed takes weak equivalences to isomorphisms: By two-out-of-three (def. ) applied to the commuting diagrams shown in the proof of lemma , the morphism PQfP Q f is a weak equivalence if ff is:

X ‚üµ‚âÉp X QX ‚ü∂‚âÉj QX PQX f‚Üì ‚Üì Qf ‚Üì PQf (Y ‚üµp y‚âÉ QY ‚ü∂j QY‚âÉ PQY \array{ X &\underoverset{\simeq}{p_X}{\longleftarrow}& Q X &\underoverset{\simeq}{j_{Q X}}{\longrightarrow}& P Q X \\ {}^{\mathllap{f}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{Q f}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{P Q f}} \\( Y &\underoverset{p_y}{\simeq}{\longleftarrow}& Q Y &\underoverset{j_{Q Y}}{\simeq}{\longrightarrow}& P Q Y }

With this the ‚ÄúWhitehead theorem for model categories‚Äù, lemma , implies that PQfP Q f represents an isomorphism in Ho(ùíû)Ho(\mathcal{C}).

Now let F:ùíû‚ü∂DF \colon \mathcal{C}\longrightarrow D be any functor that sends weak equivalences to isomorphisms. We need to show that it factors as

ùíû ‚ü∂F D Œ≥‚Üò ‚áì œÅ ‚Üó FÀú Ho(ùíû) \array{ \mathcal{C} && \overset{F}{\longrightarrow} && D \\ & {}_{\mathllap{\gamma}}\searrow &\Downarrow^{\rho}& \nearrow_{\mathrlap{\tilde F}} \\ && Ho(\mathcal{C}) }

uniquely up to unique natural isomorphism. Now by construction of PP and QQ in def. , Œ≥ P,Q\gamma_{P,Q} is the identity on the full subcategory of fibrant-cofibrant objects. It follows that if FÀú\tilde F exists at all, it must satisfy for all X‚ÜífYX \stackrel{f}{\to} Y with XX and YY both fibrant and cofibrant that

FÀú([f])‚âÉF(f), \tilde F([f]) \simeq F(f) \,,

(hence in particular FÀú(Œ≥ P,Q(f))‚âÉF(PQf)\tilde F(\gamma_{P,Q}(f)) \simeq F(P Q f)).

But by def. that already fixes FÀú\tilde F on all of Ho(ùíû)Ho(\mathcal{C}), up to unique natural isomorphism. Hence it only remains to check that with this definition of FÀú\tilde F there exists any natural isomorphism œÅ\rho filling the diagram above.

To that end, apply FF to the above commuting diagram to obtain

F(X) ‚üµisoF(p X) F(QX) ‚ü∂isoF(j QX) F(PQX) F(f)‚Üì ‚Üì F(Qf) ‚Üì F(PQf) F(Y) ‚üµF(p y)iso F(QY) ‚ü∂F(j QY)iso F(PQY). \array{ F(X) &\underoverset{iso}{F(p_X)}{\longleftarrow}& F(Q X) &\underoverset{iso}{F(j_{Q X})}{\longrightarrow}& F(P Q X) \\ {}^{\mathllap{F(f)}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{F(Q f)}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{F(P Q f)}} \\ F(Y) &\underoverset{F(p_y)}{iso}{\longleftarrow}& F(Q Y) &\underoverset{F(j_{Q Y})}{iso}{\longrightarrow}& F(P Q Y) } \,.

Here now all horizontal morphisms are isomorphisms, by assumption on FF. It follows that defining œÅ X‚âîF(j QX)‚àòF(p X) ‚àí1\rho_X \coloneqq F(j_{Q X}) \circ F(p_X)^{-1} makes the required natural isomorphism:

œÅ X: F(X) ‚ü∂isoF(p X) ‚àí1 F(QX) ‚ü∂isoF(j QX) F(PQX) = FÀú(Œ≥ P,Q(X)) F(f)‚Üì ‚Üì F(PQf) ‚Üì FÀú(Œ≥ P,Q(f)) œÅ Y: F(Y) ‚ü∂F(p y) ‚àí1iso F(QY) ‚ü∂F(j QY)iso F(PQY) = FÀú(Œ≥ P,Q(X)). \array{ \rho_X \colon & F(X) &\underoverset{iso}{F(p_X)^{-1}}{\longrightarrow}& F(Q X) &\underoverset{iso}{F(j_{Q X})}{\longrightarrow}& F(P Q X) &=& \tilde F(\gamma_{P,Q}(X)) \\ & {}^{\mathllap{F(f)}}\downarrow && && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{F(P Q f)}} && \downarrow^{\tilde F(\gamma_{P,Q}(f))} \\ \rho_Y\colon& F(Y) &\underoverset{F(p_y)^{-1}}{iso}{\longrightarrow}& F(Q Y) &\underoverset{F(j_{Q Y})}{iso}{\longrightarrow}& F(P Q Y) &=& \tilde F(\gamma_{P,Q}(X)) } \,.
Remark

Due to theorem we may suppress the choices of cofibrant QQ and fibrant replacement PP in def. and just speak of the localization functor

Œ≥:ùíû‚ü∂Ho(ùíû) \gamma \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow Ho(\mathcal{C})

up to natural isomorphism.

In general, the localization ùíû[W ‚àí1]\mathcal{C}[W^{-1}] of a category with weak equivalences (ùíû,W)(\mathcal{C},W) (def. ) may invert more morphisms than just those in WW. However, if the category admits the structure of a model category (ùíû,W,Cof,Fib)(\mathcal{C},W,Cof,Fib), then its localization precisely only inverts the weak equivalences:

Proposition

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a model category (def. ) and let Œ≥:ùíû‚ü∂Ho(ùíû)\gamma \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow Ho(\mathcal{C}) be its localization functor (def. , theorem ). Then a morphism ff in ùíû\mathcal{C} is a weak equivalence precisely if Œ≥(f)\gamma(f) is an isomorphism in Ho(ùíû)Ho(\mathcal{C}).

(e.g. Goerss-Jardine 96, II, prop 1.14)

While the construction of the homotopy category in def. combines the restriction to good (fibrant/cofibrant) objects with the passage to homotopy classes of morphisms, it is often useful to consider intermediate stages:

Definition

Given a model category ùíû\mathcal{C}, write

ùíû fc ‚Üô ‚Üò ùíû c ùíû f ‚Üò ‚Üô ùíû \array{ && \mathcal{C}_{f c} \\ & \swarrow && \searrow \\ \mathcal{C}_c && && \mathcal{C}_f \\ & \searrow && \swarrow \\ && \mathcal{C} }

for the system of full subcategory inclusions of:

  1. the category of fibrant objects ùíû f\mathcal{C}_f

  2. the category of cofibrant objects ùíû c\mathcal{C}_c,

  3. the category of fibrant-cofibrant objects ùíû fc\mathcal{C}_{fc},

all regarded a categories with weak equivalences (def. ), via the weak equivalences inherited from ùíû\mathcal{C}, which we write (ùíû f,W f)(\mathcal{C}_f, W_f), (ùíû c,W c)(\mathcal{C}_c, W_c) and (ùíû fc,W fc)(\mathcal{C}_{f c}, W_{f c}).

Remark

Of course the subcategories in def. inherit more structure than just that of categories with weak equivalences from ùíû\mathcal{C}. ùíû f\mathcal{C}_f and ùíû c\mathcal{C}_c each inherit ‚Äúhalf‚Äù of the factorization axioms. One says that ùíû f\mathcal{C}_f has the structure of a ‚Äúfibration category‚Äù called a ‚ÄúBrown-category of fibrant objects‚Äù, while ùíû c\mathcal{C}_c has the structure of a ‚Äúcofibration category‚Äù.

We discuss properties of these categories of (co-)fibrant objects below in Homotopy fiber sequences.

The proof of theorem immediately implies the following:

Corollary

For ùíû\mathcal{C} a model category, the restriction of the localization functor Œ≥:ùíû‚ü∂Ho(ùíû)\gamma\;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow Ho(\mathcal{C}) from def. (using remark ) to any of the sub-categories with weak equivalences of def.

ùíû fc ‚Üô ‚Üò ùíû c ùíû f ‚Üò ‚Üô ùíû ‚Üì Œ≥ Ho(ùíû) \array{ && \mathcal{C}_{f c} \\ & \swarrow && \searrow \\ \mathcal{C}_c && && \mathcal{C}_f \\ & \searrow && \swarrow \\ && \mathcal{C} \\ && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\gamma}} \\ && Ho(\mathcal{C}) }

exhibits Ho(ùíû)Ho(\mathcal{C}) equivalently as the localization also of these subcategories with weak equivalences, at their weak equivalences. In particular there are equivalences of categories

Ho(ùíû)‚âÉùíû[W ‚àí1]‚âÉùíû f[W f ‚àí1]‚âÉùíû c[W c ‚àí1]‚âÉùíû fc[W fc ‚àí1]. Ho(\mathcal{C}) \simeq \mathcal{C}[W^{-1}] \simeq \mathcal{C}_f[W_f^{-1}] \simeq \mathcal{C}_c[W_c^{-1}] \simeq \mathcal{C}_{f c}[W_{f c}^{-1}] \,.

The following says that for computing the hom-sets in the homotopy category, even a mixed variant of the above will do; it is sufficient that the domain is cofibrant and the codomain is fibrant:

Lemma

For X,Y‚ààùíûX, Y \in \mathcal{C} with XX cofibrant and YY fibrant, and for P,QP, Q fibrant/cofibrant replacement functors as in def. , the morphism

Hom Ho(ùíû)(PX,QY)=Hom ùíû(PX,QY)/ ‚àº‚ü∂Hom ùíû(j X,p Y)Hom ùíû(X,Y)/ ‚àº Hom_{Ho(\mathcal{C})}(P X,Q Y) = Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(P X, Q Y)/_{\sim} \overset{Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(j_X, p_Y)}{\longrightarrow} Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(X,Y)/_{\sim}

(on homotopy classes of morphisms, well defined by prop. ) is a natural bijection.

(Quillen 67, I.1 corollary 1)

Proof

We may factor the morphism in question as the composite

Hom ùíû(PX,QY)/ ‚àº‚ü∂Hom ùíû(id PX,p Y)/ ‚àºHom ùíû(PX,Y)/ ‚àº‚ü∂Hom ùíû(j X,id Y)/ ‚àºHom ùíû(X,Y)/ ‚àº. Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(P X, Q Y)/_{\sim} \overset{Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(id_{P X}, p_Y)/_\sim }{\longrightarrow} Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(P X, Y)/_{\sim} \overset{Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(j_X, id_Y)/_\sim}{\longrightarrow} Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(X,Y)/_{\sim} \,.

This shows that it is sufficient to see that for XX cofibrant and YY fibrant, then

Hom ùíû(id X,p Y)/ ‚àº:Hom ùíû(X,QY)/ ‚àº‚ÜíHom ùíû(X,Y)/ ‚àº Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(id_X, p_Y)/_\sim \;\colon\; Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(X, Q Y)/_\sim \to Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(X,Y)/_\sim

is an isomorphism, and dually that

Hom ùíû(j X,id Y)/ ‚àº:Hom ùíû(PX,Y)/ ‚àº‚ÜíHom ùíû(X,Y)/ ‚àº Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(j_X, id_Y)/_\sim \;\colon\; Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(P X, Y)/_\sim \to Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(X,Y)/_\sim

is an isomorphism. We discuss this for the former; the second is formally dual:

First, that Hom ùíû(id X,p Y)Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(id_X, p_Y) is surjective is the lifting property in

‚àÖ ‚ü∂ QY ‚ààCof‚Üì ‚Üì ‚ààW‚à©Fib p Y X ‚ü∂f Y, \array{ \emptyset &\longrightarrow& Q Y \\ {}^{\mathllap{\in Cof}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p_Y}}_{\mathrlap{\in W \cap Fib}} \\ X &\overset{f}{\longrightarrow}& Y } \,,

which says that any morphism f:X‚ÜíYf \colon X \to Y comes from a morphism f^:X‚ÜíQY\hat f \colon X \to Q Y under postcomposition with QY‚Üíp YYQ Y \overset{p_Y}{\to} Y.

Second, that Hom ùíû(id X,p Y)Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(id_X, p_Y) is injective is the lifting property in

X‚äîX ‚ü∂(f,g) QY ‚ààCof‚Üì ‚Üì ‚ààW‚à©Fib p Y Cyl(X) ‚ü∂Œ∑ Y, \array{ X \sqcup X &\overset{(f,g)}{\longrightarrow}& Q Y \\ {}^{\mathllap{\in Cof}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p_Y}}_{\mathrlap{\in W \cap Fib}} \\ Cyl(X) &\underset{\eta}{\longrightarrow}& Y } \,,

which says that if two morphisms f,g:X‚ÜíQYf, g \colon X \to Q Y become homotopic after postcomposition with p Y:QX‚ÜíYp_Y \colon Q X \to Y, then they were already homotopic before.

We record the following fact which will be used in part 1.1 (here):

Lemma

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a model category (def. ). Then every commuting square in its homotopy category Ho(C)Ho(C) (def. ) is, up to isomorphism of squares, in the image of the localization functor ùíû‚ü∂Ho(ùíû)\mathcal{C} \longrightarrow Ho(\mathcal{C}) of a commuting square in ùíû\mathcal{C} (i.e.: not just commuting up to homotopy).

Proof

Let

A ‚ü∂f B a‚Üì ‚Üì b A‚Ä≤ ‚ü∂f‚Ä≤ B‚Ä≤‚ààHo(ùíû) \array{ A &\overset{f}{\longrightarrow}& B \\ {}^{\mathllap{a}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{b}} \\ A' &\underset{f'}{\longrightarrow}& B' } \;\;\;\;\; \in Ho(\mathcal{C})

be a commuting square in the homotopy category. Writing the same symbols for fibrant-cofibrant objects in ùíû\mathcal{C} and for morphisms in ùíû\mathcal{C} representing these, then this means that in ùíû\mathcal{C} there is a left homotopy of the form

A ‚ü∂f B i 1‚Üì ‚Üì b Cyl(A) ‚ü∂Œ∑ B‚Ä≤ i 0‚Üë ‚Üë f‚Ä≤ A ‚ü∂a A‚Ä≤. \array{ A &\overset{f}{\longrightarrow}& B \\ {}^{\mathllap{i_1}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{b}} \\ Cyl(A) &\underset{\eta}{\longrightarrow}& B' \\ {}^{\mathllap{i_0}}\uparrow && \uparrow^{\mathrlap{f'}} \\ A &\underset{a}{\longrightarrow}& A' } \,.

Consider the factorization of the top square here through the mapping cylinder of ff

A ‚ü∂f B i 1‚Üì (po) ‚Üì ‚ààW Cyl(A) ‚ü∂ Cyl(f) i 0‚Üë Œ∑‚Üò ‚Üì A B‚Ä≤ a‚Üò ‚Üë f‚Ä≤ A‚Ä≤ \array{ A &\overset{f}{\longrightarrow}& B \\ {}^{\mathllap{i_1}}\downarrow &(po)& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in W}} \\ Cyl(A) &\underset{}{\longrightarrow}& Cyl(f) \\ {}^{\mathllap{i_0}}\uparrow &{}_{\mathllap{\eta}}\searrow& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{}} \\ A && B' \\ & {}_{\mathllap{a}}\searrow & \uparrow_{\mathrlap{f'}} \\ && A' }

This exhibits the composite A‚Üíi 0Cyl(A)‚ÜíCyl(f)A \overset{i_0}{\to} Cyl(A) \to Cyl(f) as an alternative representative of ff in Ho(ùíû)Ho(\mathcal{C}), and Cyl(f)‚ÜíB‚Ä≤Cyl(f) \to B' as an alternative representative for bb, and the commuting square

A ‚ü∂ Cyl(f) a‚Üì ‚Üì A‚Ä≤ ‚ü∂f‚Ä≤ B‚Ä≤ \array{ A &\overset{}{\longrightarrow}& Cyl(f) \\ {}^{\mathllap{a}}\downarrow && \downarrow \\ A' &\underset{f'}{\longrightarrow}& B' }

as an alternative representative of the given commuting square in Ho(ùíû)Ho(\mathcal{C}).

Derived functors

Definition

For ùíû\mathcal{C} and ùíü\mathcal{D} two categories with weak equivalences, def. , then a functor F:ùíû‚ü∂ùíüF \colon \mathcal{C}\longrightarrow \mathcal{D} is called a homotopical functor if it sends weak equivalences to weak equivalences.

Definition

Given a homotopical functor F:ùíû‚ü∂ùíüF \colon \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow \mathcal{D} (def. ) between categories with weak equivalences whose homotopy categories Ho(ùíû)Ho(\mathcal{C}) and Ho(ùíü)Ho(\mathcal{D}) exist (def. ), then its (‚Äútotal‚Äù) derived functor is the functor Ho(F)Ho(F) between these homotopy categories which is induced uniquely, up to unique isomorphism, by their universal property (def. ):

ùíû ‚ü∂F ùíü Œ≥ ùíû‚Üì ‚áô ‚âÉ ‚Üì Œ≥ ùíü Ho(ùíû) ‚ü∂‚àÉHo(F) Ho(ùíü). \array{ \mathcal{C} &\overset{F}{\longrightarrow}& \mathcal{D} \\ {}^{\mathllap{\gamma_{\mathcal{C}}}}\downarrow &\swArrow_{\simeq}& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\gamma_{\mathcal{D}}}} \\ Ho(\mathcal{C}) &\underset{\exists \; Ho(F)}{\longrightarrow}& Ho(\mathcal{D}) } \,.
Remark

While many functors of interest between model categories are not homotopical in the sense of def. , many become homotopical after restriction to the full subcategories ùíû f\mathcal{C}_f of fibrant objects or ùíû c\mathcal{C}_c of cofibrant objects, def. . By corollary this is just as good for the purpose of homotopy theory.

Therefore one considers the following generalization of def. :

Definition

(left and right derived functors)

Consider a functor F:ùíû‚ü∂ùíüF \colon \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow \mathcal{D} out of a model category ùíû\mathcal{C} (def. ) into a category with weak equivalences ùíü\mathcal{D} (def. ).

  1. If the restriction of FF to the full subcategory ùíû f\mathcal{C}_f of fibrant object becomes a homotopical functor (def. ), then the derived functor of that restriction, according to def. , is called the right derived functor of FF and denoted by ‚ÑùF\mathbb{R}F:

    ùíû f ‚Ü™ ùíû ‚ü∂F ùíü Œ≥ ùíû f‚Üì ‚áô ‚âÉ ‚Üì Œ≥ ùíü ‚ÑùF: ùíû f[W ‚àí1] ‚âÉ Ho(ùíû) ‚ü∂Ho(F) Ho(ùíü), \array{ & \mathcal{C}_f &\hookrightarrow& \mathcal{C} &\overset{F}{\longrightarrow}& \mathcal{D} \\ & {}^{\mathllap{\gamma}_{\mathcal{C}_f}} \downarrow && \swArrow_{\simeq} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\gamma_{\mathcal{D}}}} \\ \mathbb{R} F \colon & \mathcal{C}_f[W^{-1}] &\simeq& Ho(\mathcal{C}) &\underset{Ho(F)}{\longrightarrow}& Ho(\mathcal{D}) } \,,

    where we use corollary .

  2. If the restriction of FF to the full subcategory ùíû c\mathcal{C}_c of cofibrant object becomes a homotopical functor (def. ), then the derived functor of that restriction, according to def. , is called the left derived functor of FF and denoted by ùïÉF\mathbb{L}F:

    ùíû c ‚Ü™ ùíû ‚ü∂F ùíü Œ≥ ùíû f‚Üì ‚áô ‚âÉ ‚Üì Œ≥ ùíü ùïÉF: ùíû c[W ‚àí1] ‚âÉ Ho(ùíû) ‚ü∂Ho(F) Ho(ùíü), \array{ & \mathcal{C}_c &\hookrightarrow& \mathcal{C} &\overset{F}{\longrightarrow}& \mathcal{D} \\ & {}^{\mathllap{\gamma}_{\mathcal{C}_f}}\downarrow && \swArrow_{\simeq} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\gamma_{\mathcal{D}}}} \\ \mathbb{L} F \colon & \mathcal{C}_c[W^{-1}] &\simeq& Ho(\mathcal{C}) &\underset{Ho(F)}{\longrightarrow}& Ho(\mathcal{D}) } \,,

    where again we use corollary .

The key fact that makes def. practically relevant is the following:

Proposition

(Ken Brown's lemma)

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a model category with full subcategories ùíû f,ùíû c\mathcal{C}_f, \mathcal{C}_c of fibrant objects and of cofibrant objects respectively (def. ). Let ùíü\mathcal{D} be a category with weak equivalences.

  1. A functor out of the category of fibrant objects

    F:ùíû f‚ü∂ùíü F \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}_f \longrightarrow \mathcal{D}

    is a homotopical functor, def. , already if it sends acylic fibrations to weak equivalences.

  2. A functor out of the category of cofibrant objects

    F:ùíû c‚ü∂ùíü F \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}_c \longrightarrow \mathcal{D}

    is a homotopical functor, def. , already if it sends acylic cofibrations to weak equivalences.

The following proof refers to the factorization lemma, whose full statement and proof we postpone to further below (lemma ).

Proof

We discuss the case of a functor on a category of fibrant objects ùíû f\mathcal{C}_f, def. . The other case is formally dual.

Let f:X‚ü∂Yf \colon X \longrightarrow Y be a weak equivalence in ùíû f\mathcal{C}_f. Choose a path space object Path(X)Path(X) (def. ) and consider the diagram

Path(f) ‚ü∂‚ààW‚à©Fib X ‚ààW p 1 *f‚Üì (pb) ‚Üì ‚ààW f Path(Y) ‚ü∂‚ààW‚à©Fibp 1 Y ‚ààW‚à©Fib p 0‚Üì Y, \array{ Path(f) &\underset{\in W \cap Fib}{\longrightarrow}& X \\ {}^{\mathllap{p_1^\ast f}}_{\mathllap{\in W}}\downarrow &(pb)& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}}_{\mathrlap{\in W}} \\ Path(Y) &\overset{p_1}{\underset{\in W \cap Fib}{\longrightarrow}}& Y \\ {}^{\mathllap{p_0}}_{\mathllap{\in W \cap Fib}}\downarrow \\ Y } \,,

where the square is a pullback and Path(f)Path(f) on the top left is our notation for the universal cone object. (Below we discuss this in more detail, it is the mapping cocone of ff, def. ).

Here:

  1. p ip_i are both acyclic fibrations, by lemma ;

  2. Path(f)‚ÜíXPath(f) \to X is an acyclic fibration because it is the pullback of p 1p_1.

  3. p 1 *fp_1^\ast f is a weak equivalence, because the factorization lemma states that the composite vertical morphism factors ff through a weak equivalence, hence if ff is a weak equivalence, then p 1 *fp_1^\ast f is by two-out-of-three (def. ).

Now apply the functor FF to this diagram and use the assumption that it sends acyclic fibrations to weak equivalences to obtain

F(Path(f)) ‚ü∂‚ààW F(X) F(p 1 *f)‚Üì ‚Üì F(f) F(Path(Y)) ‚ü∂‚ààWF(p 1) F(Y) ‚ààW F(p 0)‚Üì Y. \array{ F(Path(f)) &\underset{\in W }{\longrightarrow}& F(X) \\ {}^{\mathllap{F(p_1^\ast f)}}_{\mathllap{}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{F(f)}} \\ F(Path(Y)) &\overset{F(p_1)}{\underset{\in W }{\longrightarrow}}& F(Y) \\ {}^{\mathllap{F(p_0)}}_{\mathllap{\in W}}\downarrow \\ Y } \,.

But the factorization lemma , in addition says that the vertical composite p 0‚àòp 1 *fp_0 \circ p_1^\ast f is a fibration, hence an acyclic fibration by the above. Therefore also F(p 0‚àòp 1 *f)F(p_0 \circ p_1^\ast f) is a weak equivalence. Now the claim that also F(f)F(f) is a weak equivalence follows with applying two-out-of-three (def. ) twice.

Corollary

Let ùíû,ùíü\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{D} be model categories and consider F:ùíû‚ü∂ùíüF \colon \mathcal{C}\longrightarrow \mathcal{D} a functor. Then:

  1. If FF preserves cofibrant objects and acyclic cofibrations between these, then its left derived functor (def. ) ùïÉF\mathbb{L}F exists, fitting into a diagram

    ùíû c ‚ü∂F ùíü c Œ≥ ùíû‚Üì ‚áô ‚âÉ ‚Üì Œ≥ ùíü Ho(ùíû) ‚ü∂ùïÉF Ho(ùíü) \array{ \mathcal{C}_{c} &\overset{F}{\longrightarrow}& \mathcal{D}_{c} \\ {}^{\mathllap{\gamma_{\mathcal{C}}}}\downarrow &\swArrow_{\simeq}& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\gamma_{\mathcal{D}}}} \\ Ho(\mathcal{C}) &\overset{\mathbb{L}F}{\longrightarrow}& Ho(\mathcal{D}) }

  2. If FF preserves fibrant objects and acyclic fibrants between these, then its right derived functor (def. ) ‚ÑùF\mathbb{R}F exists, fitting into a diagram

    ùíû f ‚ü∂F ùíü f Œ≥ ùíû‚Üì ‚áô ‚âÉ ‚Üì Œ≥ ùíü Ho(ùíû) ‚ü∂‚ÑùF Ho(ùíü). \array{ \mathcal{C}_{f} &\overset{F}{\longrightarrow}& \mathcal{D}_{f} \\ {}^{\mathllap{\gamma_{\mathcal{C}}}}\downarrow &\swArrow_{\simeq}& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\gamma_{\mathcal{D}}}} \\ Ho(\mathcal{C}) &\underset{\mathbb{R}F}{\longrightarrow}& Ho(\mathcal{D}) } \,.
Proposition

Let F:ùíû‚ü∂ùíüF \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow \mathcal{D} be a functor between two model categories (def. ).

  1. If FF preserves fibrant objects and weak equivalences between fibrant objects, then the total right derived functor ‚ÑùF‚âî‚Ñù(Œ≥ ùíü‚àòF)\mathbb{R}F \coloneqq \mathbb{R}(\gamma_{\mathcal{D}}\circ F) (def. ) in

    ùíû f ‚ü∂F ùíü Œ≥ ùíû f‚Üì ‚áô ‚âÉ ‚Üì Œ≥ ùíü Ho(ùíû) ‚ü∂‚ÑùF Ho(ùíü) \array{ \mathcal{C}_f &\overset{F}{\longrightarrow}& \mathcal{D} \\ {}^{\mathllap{\gamma_{\mathcal{C}_f}}}\downarrow &\swArrow_{\simeq}& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\gamma_{\mathcal{D}}}} \\ Ho(\mathcal{C}) &\underset{\mathbb{R}F}{\longrightarrow}& Ho(\mathcal{D}) }

    is given, up to isomorphism, on any object X‚ààùíû‚ü∂Œ≥ ùíûHo(ùíû) X\in \mathcal{C} \overset{\gamma_{\mathcal{C}}}{\longrightarrow} Ho(\mathcal{C}) by appying FF to a fibrant replacement PXP X of XX and then forming a cofibrant replacement Q(F(PX))Q(F(P X)) of the result:

‚ÑùF(X)‚âÉQ(F(PX)). \mathbb{R}F(X) \simeq Q(F(P X)) \,.

  1. If FF preserves cofibrant objects and weak equivalences between cofibrant objects, then the total left derived functor ùïÉF‚âîùïÉ(Œ≥ ùíü‚àòF)\mathbb{L}F \coloneqq \mathbb{L}(\gamma_{\mathcal{D}}\circ F) (def. ) in

    ùíû c ‚ü∂F ùíü Œ≥ ùíû c‚Üì ‚áô ‚âÉ ‚Üì Œ≥ ùíü Ho(ùíû) ‚ü∂ùïÉF Ho(ùíü) \array{ \mathcal{C}_c &\overset{F}{\longrightarrow}& \mathcal{D} \\ {}^{\mathllap{\gamma_{\mathcal{C}_c}}}\downarrow &\swArrow_{\simeq}& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\gamma_{\mathcal{D}}}} \\ Ho(\mathcal{C}) &\underset{\mathbb{L}F}{\longrightarrow}& Ho(\mathcal{D}) }

    is given, up to isomorphism, on any object X‚ààùíû‚ü∂Œ≥ ùíûHo(ùíû) X\in \mathcal{C} \overset{\gamma_{\mathcal{C}}}{\longrightarrow} Ho(\mathcal{C}) by appying FF to a cofibrant replacement QXQ X of XX and then forming a fibrant replacement P(F(QX))P(F(Q X)) of the result:

ùïÉF(X)‚âÉP(F(QX)). \mathbb{L}F(X) \simeq P(F(Q X)) \,.
Proof

We discuss the first case, the second is formally dual. By the proof of theorem we have

‚ÑùF(X) ‚âÉŒ≥ ùíü(F(Œ≥ ùíû)) ‚âÉŒ≥ ùíüF(Q(P(X))). \begin{aligned} \mathbb{R}F(X) & \simeq \gamma_{\mathcal{D}}(F(\gamma_{\mathcal{C}})) \\ & \simeq \gamma_{\mathcal{D}}F(Q(P(X)) ) \end{aligned} \,.

But since FF is a homotopical functor on fibrant objects, the cofibrant replacement morphism F(Q(P(X)))‚ÜíF(P(X))F(Q(P(X)))\to F(P(X)) is a weak equivalence in ùíü\mathcal{D}, hence becomes an isomorphism under Œ≥ ùíü\gamma_{\mathcal{D}}. Therefore

‚ÑùF(X)‚âÉŒ≥ ùíü(F(P(X))). \mathbb{R}F(X) \simeq \gamma_{\mathcal{D}}(F(P(X))) \,.

Now since FF is assumed to preserve fibrant objects, F(P(X))F(P(X)) is fibrant in ùíü\mathcal{D}, and hence Œ≥ ùíü\gamma_{\mathcal{D}} acts on it (only) by cofibrant replacement.

Quillen adjunctions

In practice it turns out to be useful to arrange for the assumptions in corollary to be satisfied by pairs of adjoint functors. Recall that this is a pair of functors LL and RR going back and forth between two categories

ùíû‚ü∂R‚üµLùíü \mathcal{C} \underoverset {\underset{R}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{L}{\longleftarrow}} {} \mathcal{D}

such that there is a natural bijection between hom-sets with LL on the left and those with RR on the right:

œï d,c:Hom ùíû(L(d),c)‚ü∂‚âÉHom ùíü(d,R(c)) \phi_{d,c} \;\colon\; Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(L(d),c) \underoverset{\simeq}{}{\longrightarrow} Hom_{\mathcal{D}}(d, R(c))

for all objects d‚ààùíüd\in \mathcal{D} and c‚ààùíûc \in \mathcal{C}. This being natural means that œï:Hom ùíü(L(‚àí),‚àí)‚áíHom ùíû(‚àí,R(‚àí))\phi \colon Hom_{\mathcal{D}}(L(-),-) \Rightarrow Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(-, R(-)) is a natural transformation, hence that for all morphisms g:d 2‚Üíd 1g \colon d_2 \to d_1 and f:c 1‚Üíc 2f \colon c_1 \to c_2 the following is a commuting square:

Hom ùíû(L(d 1),c 1) ‚ü∂‚âÉœï d 1,c 1 Hom ùíü(d 1,R(c 1)) L(f)‚àò(‚àí)‚àòg‚Üì ‚Üì g‚àò(‚àí)‚àòR(g) Hom ùíû(L(d 2),c 2) ‚ü∂œï d 2,c 2‚âÉ Hom ùíü(d 2,R(c 2)). \array{ Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(L(d_1), c_1) & \underoverset{\simeq}{\phi_{d_1,c_1}}{\longrightarrow} & Hom_{\mathcal{D}}(d_1, R(c_1)) \\ {}^{\mathllap{L(f) \circ (-)\circ g}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{g\circ (-)\circ R(g)}} \\ Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(L(d_2), c_2) & \underoverset{\phi_{d_2, c_2}}{\simeq}{\longrightarrow} & Hom_{\mathcal{D}}(d_2, R(c_2)) } \,.

We write (L‚ä£R)(L \dashv R) to indicate an adjunction and call LL the left adjoint and RR the right adjoint of the adjoint pair.

The archetypical example of a pair of adjoint functors is that consisting of forming Cartesian products Y√ó(‚àí)Y \times (-) and forming mapping spaces (‚àí) Y(-)^Y, as in the category of compactly generated topological spaces of def. .

If f:L(d)‚Üícf \colon L(d) \to c is any morphism, then the image œï d,c(f):d‚ÜíR(c)\phi_{d,c}(f) \colon d \to R(c) is called its adjunct, and conversely. The fact that adjuncts are in bijection is also expressed by the notation

L(c)‚ü∂fdc‚ü∂fÀúR(d). \frac{ L(c) \overset{f}{\longrightarrow} d }{ c \overset{\tilde f}{\longrightarrow} R(d) } \,.

For an object d‚ààùíüd\in \mathcal{D}, the adjunct of the identity on LdL d is called the adjunction unit Œ∑ d:d‚ü∂RLd\eta_d \;\colon\; d \longrightarrow R L d.

For an object c‚ààùíûc \in \mathcal{C}, the adjunct of the identity on RcR c is called the adjunction counit œµ c:LRc‚ü∂c\epsilon_c \;\colon\; L R c \longrightarrow c.

Adjunction units and counits turn out to encode the adjuncts of all other morphisms by the formulas

  • (Ld‚Üífc)Àú=(d‚ÜíŒ∑RLd‚ÜíRfRc)\widetilde{(L d\overset{f}{\to}c)} = (d\overset{\eta}{\to} R L d \overset{R f}{\to} R c)

  • (d‚ÜígRc)Àú=(Ld‚ÜíLgLRc‚Üíœµc)\widetilde{(d\overset{g}{\to} R c)} = (L d \overset{L g}{\to} L R c \overset{\epsilon}{\to} c).

Definition

Let ùíû,ùíü\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{D} be model categories. A pair of adjoint functors between them

(L‚ä£R):ùíû‚ü∂R‚üµLùíü (L \dashv R) \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \underoverset {\underset{R}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{L}{\longleftarrow}} {} \mathcal{D}

is called a Quillen adjunction (and LL,RR are called left/right Quillen functors, respectively) if the following equivalent conditions are satisfied

  1. LL preserves cofibrations and RR preserves fibrations;

  2. LL preserves acyclic cofibrations and RR preserves acyclic fibrations;

  3. LL preserves cofibrations and acylic cofibrations;

  4. RR preserves fibrations and acyclic fibrations.

Proposition

The conditions in def. are indeed all equivalent.

(Quillen 67, I.4, theorem 3)

Proof

First observe that

  • (i) A left adjoint LL between model categories preserves acyclic cofibrations precisely if its right adjoint RR preserves fibrations.

  • (ii) A left adjoint LL between model categories preserves cofibrations precisely if its right adjoint RR preserves acyclic fibrations.

We discuss statement (i), statement (ii) is formally dual. So let f:A‚ÜíBf\colon A \to B be an acyclic cofibration in ùíü\mathcal{D} and g:X‚ÜíYg \colon X \to Y a fibration in ùíû\mathcal{C}. Then for every commuting diagram as on the left of the following, its (L‚ä£R)(L\dashv R)-adjunct is a commuting diagram as on the right here:

A ‚ü∂ R(X) f‚Üì ‚Üì R(g) B ‚ü∂ R(Y),L(A) ‚ü∂ X L(f)‚Üì ‚Üì g L(B) ‚ü∂ Y. \array{ A &\longrightarrow& R(X) \\ {}^{\mathllap{f}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{R(g)}} \\ B &\longrightarrow& R(Y) } \;\;\;\;\;\; \,, \;\;\;\;\;\; \array{ L(A) &\longrightarrow& X \\ {}^{\mathllap{L(f)}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{g}} \\ L(B) &\longrightarrow& Y } \,.

If LL preserves acyclic cofibrations, then the diagram on the right has a lift, and so the (L‚ä£R)(L\dashv R)-adjunct of that lift is a lift of the left diagram. This shows that R(g)R(g) has the right lifting property against all acylic cofibrations and hence is a fibration. Conversely, if RR preserves fibrations, the same argument run from right to left gives that LL preserves acyclic fibrations.

Now by repeatedly applying (i) and (ii), all four conditions in question are seen to be equivalent.

Lemma

Let ùíû‚ü∂R‚ä•‚üµLùíü\mathcal{C} \stackrel{\overset{L}{\longleftarrow}}{\underoverset{R}{\bot}{\longrightarrow}} \mathcal{D} be a Quillen adjunction, def. .

  1. For X‚ààùíûX \in \mathcal{C} a fibrant object and Path(X)Path(X) a path space object (def. ), then R(Path(X))R(Path(X)) is a path space object for R(X)R(X).

  2. For X‚ààùíûX \in \mathcal{C} a cofibrant object and Cyl(X)Cyl(X) a cylinder object (def. ), then L(Cyl(X))L(Cyl(X)) is a cylinder object for L(X)L(X).

Proof

Consider the second case, the first is formally dual.

First observe that L(X‚äîX)‚âÉLX‚äîLXL(X \sqcup X) \simeq L X \sqcup L X because LL is left adjoint and hence preserves colimits, hence in particular coproducts.

Hence

L(X‚äîX‚Üí‚ààCofCyl(X))=(L(X)‚äîL(X)‚Üí‚ààCofL(Cyl(X))) L(X \sqcup X \overset{\in Cof}{\to} Cyl(X)) = (L(X) \sqcup L(X) \overset{\in Cof}{\to } L (Cyl(X)))

is a cofibration.

Second, with XX cofibrant i 0:X‚ÜíX‚äîXi_0 \colon X \to X \sqcup X is an acyclic cofibration (lemma ), and so then is

i 0:L(X)‚ü∂L(X)‚äîL(X). i_0 \; \colon \; L(X) \longrightarrow L(X) \sqcup L(X).

Therefore by two-out-of-three (def. ) LL preserves the weak equivalence Cyl(X)‚ÜíXCyl(X) \to X.

Proposition

(derived adjunction)

For ùíû‚ä• Qu‚ü∂R‚üµLùíü\mathcal{C} \underoverset{\underset{R}{\longrightarrow}}{\overset{L}{\longleftarrow}}{\bot_{Qu}}\mathcal{D} a Quillen adjunction, def. , then also the corresponding left and right derived functors, def. , via cor. , form a pair of adjoint functors

Ho(ùíû)‚ä•‚ü∂‚ÑùR‚üµùïÉLHo(ùíü). Ho(\mathcal{C}) \underoverset {\underset{\mathbb{R}R}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{\mathbb{L}L}{\longleftarrow}} {\bot} Ho(\mathcal{D}) \,.

(Quillen 67, I.4 theorem 3)

Proof

By def. and lemma it is sufficient to see that for X,Y‚ààùíûX, Y \in \mathcal{C} with XX cofibrant and YY fibrant, then there is a natural bijection

Hom ùíû(LX,Y)/ ‚àº‚âÉHom ùíü(X,RY)/ ‚àº. Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(L X , Y)/_\sim \simeq Hom_{\mathcal{D}}(X, R Y)/_\sim \,.

Since by the adjunction isomorphism for (L‚ä£R)(L \dashv R) such a natural bijection exists before passing to homotopy classes (‚àí)/ ‚àº(-)/_\sim, it is sufficient to see that this respects homotopy classes. To that end, use from lemma that with Cyl(Y)Cyl(Y) a cylinder object for YY, def. , then L(Cyl(Y))L(Cyl(Y)) is a cylinder object for L(Y)L(Y). This implies that left homotopies

(f‚áí Lg):LX‚ü∂Y (f \Rightarrow_L g) \;\colon\; L X \longrightarrow Y

given by

Œ∑:Cyl(LX)=LCyl(X)‚ü∂Y \eta \;\colon\; Cyl(L X) = L Cyl(X) \longrightarrow Y

are in bijection to left homotopies

(fÀú‚áí LgÀú):X‚ü∂RY (\tilde f \Rightarrow_L \tilde g) \;\colon\; X \longrightarrow R Y

given by

Œ∑Àú:Cyl(X)‚ü∂RX. \tilde \eta \;\colon\; Cyl(X) \longrightarrow R X \,.
Definition

For ùíû,ùíü\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{D} two model categories, a Quillen adjunction (def.)

(L‚ä£R):ùíû‚ä•‚ü∂R‚üµLùíü (L \dashv R) \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \underoverset {\underset{R}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{L}{\longleftarrow}} {\bot} \mathcal{D}

is called a Quillen equivalence, to be denoted

ùíû‚âÉ Q‚ü∂R‚üµLùíü, \mathcal{C} \underoverset {\underset{R}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{L}{\longleftarrow}} {\simeq_{\mathrlap{Q}}} \mathcal{D} \,,

if the following equivalent conditions hold.

  1. The right derived functor of RR (via prop. , corollary ) is an equivalence of categories

    ‚ÑùR:Ho(ùíû)‚ü∂‚âÉHo(ùíü). \mathbb{R}R \colon Ho(\mathcal{C}) \overset{\simeq}{\longrightarrow} Ho(\mathcal{D}) \,.

  2. The left derived functor of LL (via prop. , corollary ) is an equivalence of categories

    ùïÉL:Ho(ùíü)‚ü∂‚âÉHo(ùíû). \mathbb{L}L \colon Ho(\mathcal{D}) \overset{\simeq}{\longrightarrow} Ho(\mathcal{C}) \,.

  3. For every cofibrant object d‚ààùíüd\in \mathcal{D}, the derived adjunction unit, hence the composite

    d‚ü∂Œ∑R(L(d))‚ü∂R(j L(d))R(P(L(d))) d \overset{\eta}{\longrightarrow} R(L(d)) \overset{R(j_{L(d)})}{\longrightarrow} R(P(L(d)))

    (of the adjunction unit with any fibrant replacement PP as in def. ) is a weak equivalence;

    and for every fibrant object c‚ààùíûc \in \mathcal{C}, the derived adjunction counit, hence the composite

    L(Q(R(c)))‚ü∂L(p R(c))L(R(c))‚ü∂œµc L(Q(R(c))) \overset{L(p_{R(c)})}{\longrightarrow} L(R(c)) \overset{\epsilon}{\longrightarrow} c

    (of the adjunction counit with any cofibrant replacement as in def. ) is a weak equivalence.

  4. For every cofibrant object d‚ààùíüd \in \mathcal{D} and every fibrant object c‚ààùíûc \in \mathcal{C}, a morphism d‚ü∂R(c)d \longrightarrow R(c) is a weak equivalence precisely if its adjunct morphism L(c)‚ÜídL(c) \to d is:

    d‚ü∂‚ààW ùíüR(c)L(d)‚ü∂‚ààW ùíûc. \frac{ d \overset{\in W_{\mathcal{D}}}{\longrightarrow} R(c) }{ L(d) \overset{\in W_{\mathcal{C}}}{\longrightarrow} c } \,.
Poposition

The conditions in def. are indeed all equivalent.

(Quillen 67, I.4, theorem 3)

Proof

That 1)‚áî2)1) \Leftrightarrow 2) follows from prop. (if in an adjoint pair one is an equivalence, then so is the other).

To see the equivalence 1),2)‚áî3)1),2) \Leftrightarrow 3), notice (prop.) that a pair of adjoint functors is an equivalence of categories precisely if both the adjunction unit and the adjunction counit are natural isomorphisms. Hence it is sufficient to show that the morphisms called derived adjunction unit and derived adjunction counit above indeed represent the adjunction (co-)unit of (ùïÉL‚ä£‚ÑùR)(\mathbb{L}L \dashv \mathbb{R}R) in the homotopy category. We show this now for the adjunction unit, the case of the adjunction counit is formally dual.

To that end, first observe that for d‚ààùíü cd \in \mathcal{D}_c, then the defining commuting square for the left derived functor from def.

ùíü c ‚ü∂L ùíû Œ≥ P‚Üì ‚áô ‚âÉ ‚Üì Œ≥ P,Q Ho(ùíü) ‚ü∂ùïÉL Ho(ùíû) \array{ \mathcal{D}_c &\overset{L}{\longrightarrow}& \mathcal{C} \\ {}^{\mathllap{\gamma_P}}\downarrow &\swArrow_{\simeq}& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\gamma_{P,Q}}} \\ Ho(\mathcal{D}) &\underset{\mathbb{L}L}{\longrightarrow}& Ho(\mathcal{C}) }

(using fibrant and fibrant/cofibrant replacement functors Œ≥ P\gamma_P, Œ≥ P,Q\gamma_{P,Q} from def. with their universal property from theorem , corollary ) gives that

(ùïÉL)d‚âÉPLPd‚âÉPLd‚ààHo(ùíû), (\mathbb{L} L ) d \simeq P L P d \simeq P L d \;\;\;\; \in Ho(\mathcal{C}) \,,

where the second isomorphism holds because the left Quillen functor LL sends the acyclic cofibration j d:d‚ÜíPdj_d \colon d \to P d to a weak equivalence.

The adjunction unit of (ùïÉL‚ä£‚ÑùR)(\mathbb{L}L \dashv \mathbb{R}R) on Pd‚ààHo(ùíû)P d \in Ho(\mathcal{C}) is the image of the identity under

Hom Ho(ùíû)((ùïÉL)Pd,(ùïÉL)Pd)‚Üí‚âÉHom Ho(ùíû)(Pd,(‚ÑùR)(ùïÉL)Pd). Hom_{Ho(\mathcal{C})}((\mathbb{L}L) P d, (\mathbb{L} L) P d) \overset{\simeq}{\to} Hom_{Ho(\mathcal{C})}(P d, (\mathbb{R}R)(\mathbb{L}L) P d) \,.

By the above and the proof of prop. , that adjunction isomorphism is equivalently that of (L‚ä£R)(L \dashv R) under the isomorphism

Hom Ho(ùíû)(PLd,PLd)‚ü∂Hom(j Ld,id)Hom ùíû(Ld,PLd)/ ‚àº Hom_{Ho(\mathcal{C})}(P L d , P L d) \overset{Hom(j_{L d}, id)}{\longrightarrow} Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(L d, P L d)/_\sim

of lemma . Hence the derived adjunction unit is the (L‚ä£R)(L \dashv R)-adjunct of

Ld‚ü∂j LdPLd‚ÜíidPLd, L d \overset{j_{L d}}{\longrightarrow} P L d \overset{id}{\to} P L d \,,

which indeed (by the formula for adjuncts) is

X‚ü∂Œ∑RLd‚ü∂R(j Ld)RPLd. X \overset{\eta}{\longrightarrow} R L d \overset{R (j_{L d})}{\longrightarrow} R P L d \,.

To see that 4)‚áí3)4) \Rightarrow 3):

Consider the weak equivalence LX‚ü∂j LXPLXL X \overset{j_{L X}}{\longrightarrow} P L X. Its (L‚ä£R)(L \dashv R)-adjunct is

X‚ü∂Œ∑RLX‚ü∂Rj LXRPLX X \overset{\eta}{\longrightarrow} R L X \overset{R j_{L X}}{\longrightarrow} R P L X

by assumption 4) this is again a weak equivalence, which is the requirement for the derived unit in 3). Dually for derived counit.

To see 3)‚áí4)3) \Rightarrow 4):

Consider any f:Ld‚Üícf \colon L d \to c a weak equivalence for cofibrant dd, firbant cc. Its adjunct fÀú\tilde f sits in a commuting diagram

fÀú: d ‚ü∂Œ∑ RLd ‚ü∂Rf Rc =‚Üì ‚Üì Rj Ld ‚Üì Rj c d ‚ü∂‚ààW RPLd ‚ü∂RPf RPc, \array{ \tilde f \colon & d &\overset{\eta}{\longrightarrow}& R L d &\overset{R f}{\longrightarrow}& R c \\ & {}^{\mathllap{=}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{R j_{L d}}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{R j_c}} \\ & d &\underset{\in W}{\longrightarrow}& R P L d &\overset{R P f}{\longrightarrow}& R P c } \,,

where PfP f is any lift constructed as in def. .

This exhibits the bottom left morphism as the derived adjunction unit, hence a weak equivalence by assumption. But since ff was a weak equivalence, so is PfP f (by two-out-of-three). Thereby also RPfR P f and Rj cR j_c, are weak equivalences by Ken Brown's lemma and the assumed fibrancy of cc. Therefore by two-out-of-three (def. ) also the adjunct fÀú\tilde f is a weak equivalence.

In certain situations the conditions on a Quillen equivalence simplify. For instance:

Proposition

If in a Quillen adjunction ùíû ‚ä•‚ÜíR‚ÜêL ùíü \array{\mathcal{C} &\underoverset{\underset{R}{\to}}{\overset{L}{\leftarrow}}{\bot}& \mathcal{D}} (def. ) the right adjoint RR ‚Äúcreates weak equivalences‚Äù (in that a morphism ff in ùíû\mathcal{C} is a weak equivalence precisly if R(f)R(f) is) then (L‚ä£R)(L \dashv R) is a Quillen equivalence (def. ) precisely already if for all cofibrant objects d‚ààùíüd \in \mathcal{D} the plain adjunction unit

d‚ü∂Œ∑R(L(d)) d \overset{\eta}{\longrightarrow} R (L (d))

is a weak equivalence.

Proof

By prop. , generally, (L‚ä£R)(L \dashv R) is a Quillen equivalence precisely if

  1. for every cofibrant object d‚ààùíüd\in \mathcal{D}, the derived adjunction unit

    d‚ü∂Œ∑R(L(d))‚ü∂R(j L(d))R(P(L(d))) d \overset{\eta}{\longrightarrow} R(L(d)) \overset{R(j_{L(d)})}{\longrightarrow} R(P(L(d)))

    is a weak equivalence;

  2. for every fibrant object c‚ààùíûc \in \mathcal{C}, the derived adjunction counit

    L(Q(R(c)))‚ü∂L(p R(c))L(R(c))‚ü∂œµc L(Q(R(c))) \overset{L(p_{R(c)})}{\longrightarrow} L(R(c)) \overset{\epsilon}{\longrightarrow} c

    is a weak equivalence.

Consider the first condition: Since RR preserves the weak equivalence j L(d)j_{L(d)}, then by two-out-of-three (def. ) the composite in the first item is a weak equivalence precisely if Œ∑\eta is.

Hence it is now sufficient to show that in this case the second condition above is automatic.

Since RR also reflects weak equivalences, the composite in item two is a weak equivalence precisely if its image

R(L(Q(R(c))))‚ü∂R(L(p R(c)))R(L(R(c)))‚ü∂R(œµ)R(c) R(L(Q(R(c)))) \overset{R(L(p_{R(c))})}{\longrightarrow} R(L(R(c))) \overset{R(\epsilon)}{\longrightarrow} R(c)

under RR is.

Moreover, assuming, by the above, that Œ∑ Q(R(c))\eta_{Q(R(c))} on the cofibrant object Q(R(c))Q(R(c)) is a weak equivalence, then by two-out-of-three this composite is a weak equivalence precisely if the further composite with Œ∑\eta is

Q(R(c))‚ü∂Œ∑ Q(R(c))R(L(Q(R(c))))‚ü∂R(L(p R(c)))R(L(R(c)))‚ü∂R(œµ)R(c). Q(R(c)) \overset{\eta_{Q(R(c))}}{\longrightarrow} R(L(Q(R(c)))) \overset{R(L(p_{R(c))})}{\longrightarrow} R(L(R(c))) \overset{R(\epsilon)}{\longrightarrow} R(c) \,.

By the formula for adjuncts, this composite is the (L‚ä£R)(L\dashv R)-adjunct of the original composite, which is just p R(c)p_{R(c)}

L(Q(R(c)))‚ü∂L(p R(c))L(R(c))‚ü∂œµcQ(R(C))‚ü∂p R(c)R(c). \frac{ L(Q(R(c))) \overset{L(p_{R(c)})}{\longrightarrow} L(R(c)) \overset{\epsilon}{\longrightarrow} c }{ Q(R(C)) \overset{p_{R(c)}}{\longrightarrow} R(c) } \,.

But p R(c)p_{R(c)} is a weak equivalence by definition of cofibrant replacement.

The model structure on topological spaces

We now discuss how the category Top of topological spaces satisfies the axioms of abstract homotopy theory (model category) theory, def. .

Definition

Say that a continuous function, hence a morphism in Top, is

  • a classical weak equivalence if it is a weak homotopy equivalence, def. ;

  • a classical fibration if it is a Serre fibration, def. ;

  • a classical cofibration if it is a retract (rem. ) of a relative cell complex, def. .

and hence

  • a acyclic classical cofibration if it is a classical cofibration as well as a classical weak equivalence;

  • a acyclic classical fibration if it is a classical fibration as well as a classical weak equivalence.

Write

W cl,Fib cl,Cof cl‚äÇMor(Top) W_{cl},\;Fib_{cl},\;Cof_{cl} \subset Mor(Top)

for the classes of these morphisms, respectively.

We first prove now that the classes of morphisms in def. satisfy the conditions for a model category structure, def. (after some lemmas, this is theorem below). Then we discuss the resulting classical homotopy category (below) and then a few variant model structures whose proof follows immediately along the line of the proof of Top QuillenTop_{Quillen}:

  • The model structure on pointed topological spaces Top Quillen */Top^{\ast/}_{Quillen};

  • The model structure on compactly generated topological spaces (Top cg) Quillen(Top_{cg})_{Quillen} and (Top cg */) Quillen(Top^{\ast/}_{cg})_{Quillen};

  • The model structure on topologically enriched functors [ùíû,(Top cg) Quillen] proj[\mathcal{C}, (Top_{cg})_{Quillen}]_{proj} and [ùíû,(Top cg *) Quillen] proj[\mathcal{C},(Top^{\ast}_{cg})_{Quillen}]_{proj}.

\,

Proposition

The classical weak equivalences, def. , satify two-out-of-three (def. ).

Proof

Since isomorphisms (of homotopy groups) satisfy 2-out-of-3, this property is directly inherited via the very definition of weak homotopy equivalence, def. .

Lemma

Every morphism f:X‚ü∂Yf\colon X \longrightarrow Y in Top factors as a classical cofibration followed by an acyclic classical fibration, def. :

f:X‚ü∂‚ààCof clX^‚ü∂‚ààW cl‚à©Fib clY. f \;\colon\; X \stackrel{\in Cof_{cl}}{\longrightarrow} \hat X \stackrel{\in W_{cl} \cap Fib_{cl}}{\longrightarrow} Y \,.
Proof

By lemma the set I Top={S n‚àí1‚Ü™D n}I_{Top} = \{S^{n-1}\hookrightarrow D^n\} of topological generating cofibrations, def. , has small domains, in the sense of def. (the n-spheres are compact). Hence by the small object argument, prop. , ff factors as an I TopI_{Top}-relative cell complex, def. , hence just a plain relative cell complex, def. , followed by an I TopI_{Top}-injective morphisms, def. :

f:X‚ü∂‚ààCof clX^‚ü∂‚ààI TopInjY. f \;\colon\; X \stackrel{\in Cof_{cl}}{\longrightarrow} \hat X \stackrel{\in I_{Top} Inj}{\longrightarrow} Y \,.

By lemma the map X^‚ÜíY\hat X \to Y is both a weak homotopy equivalence as well as a Serre fibration.

Lemma

Every morphism f:X‚ü∂Yf\colon X \longrightarrow Y in Top factors as an acyclic classical cofibration followed by a fibration, def. :

f:X‚ü∂‚ààW cl‚à©Cof clX^‚ü∂‚ààFib clY. f \;\colon\; X \stackrel{\in W_{cl} \cap Cof_{cl}}{\longrightarrow} \hat X \stackrel{\in Fib_{cl}}{\longrightarrow} Y \,.
Proof

By lemma the set J Top={D n‚Ü™D n√óI}J_{Top} = \{D^n \hookrightarrow D^n\times I\} of topological generating acyclic cofibrations, def. , has small domains, in the sense of def. (the n-disks are compact). Hence by the small object argument, prop. , ff factors as an J TopJ_{Top}-relative cell complex, def. , followed by a J topJ_{top}-injective morphisms, def. :

f:X‚ü∂‚ààJ TopCellX^‚ü∂‚ààJ TopInjY. f \;\colon\; X \stackrel{\in J_{Top} Cell}{\longrightarrow} \hat X \stackrel{\in J_{Top} Inj}{\longrightarrow} Y \,.

By definition this makes X^‚ÜíY\hat X \to Y a Serre fibration, hence a fibration.

By lemma a relative J TopJ_{Top}-cell complex is in particular a relative I TopI_{Top}-cell complex. Hence X‚ÜíX^X \to \hat X is a classical cofibration. By lemma it is also a weak homotopy equivalence, hence a clasical weak equivalence.

Lemma

Every commuting square in Top with the left morphism a classical cofibration and the right morphism a fibration, def.

‚ü∂ g‚ààCof cl‚Üì ‚Üì f‚ààFib cl ‚ü∂ \array{ &\longrightarrow& \\ {}^{\mathllap{{g \in} \atop {Cof_{cl}}}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{{f \in }\atop Fib_{cl}}} \\ &\longrightarrow& }

admits a lift as soon as one of the two is also a classical weak equivalence.

Proof

A) If the fibration ff is also a weak equivalence, then lemma says that it has the right lifting property against the generating cofibrations I TopI_{Top}, and cor. implies the claim.

B) If the cofibration gg on the left is also a weak equivalence, consider any factorization into a relative J TopJ_{Top}-cell complex, def. , def. , followed by a fibration,

g:‚ü∂‚ààJ TopCell‚ü∂‚ààFib cl, g \;\colon\; \stackrel{\in J_{Top} Cell}{\longrightarrow} \stackrel{\in Fib_{cl}}{\longrightarrow} \,,

as in the proof of lemma . By lemma the morphism ‚ü∂‚ààJ TopCell\overset{\in J_{Top} Cell}{\longrightarrow} is a weak homotopy equivalence, and so by two-out-of-three (prop. ) the factorizing fibration is actually an acyclic fibration. By case A), this acyclic fibration has the right lifting property against the cofibration gg itself, and so the retract argument, lemma gives that gg is a retract of a relative J TopJ_{Top}-cell complex. With this, finally cor. implies that ff has the right lifting property against gg.

Finally:

Proposition

The systems (Cof cl,W cl‚à©Fib cl)(Cof_{cl} , W_{cl} \cap Fib_{cl}) and (W cl‚à©Cof cl,Fib cl)(W_{cl} \cap Cof_{cl}, Fib_{cl}) from def. are weak factorization systems.

Proof

Since we have already seen the factorization property (lemma , lemma ) and the lifting properties (lemma ), it only remains to see that the given left/right classes exhaust the class of morphisms with the given lifting property.

For the classical fibrations this is by definition, for the the classical acyclic fibrations this is by lemma .

The remaining statement for Cof clCof_{cl} and W cl‚à©Cof clW_{cl}\cap Cof_{cl} follows from a general argument (here) for cofibrantly generated model categories (def. ), which we spell out:

So let f:X‚ü∂Yf \colon X \longrightarrow Y be in (I TopInj)Proj(I_{Top} Inj) Proj, we need to show that then ff is a retract (remark ) of a relative cell complex. To that end, apply the small object argument as in lemma to factor ff as
